data.formatted_address: 12 Nihonodori, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0021, Japan
data.name: Museum of Yokohama Urban History

reviews.text:
If you exit from Exit 3 of Nihon-Odori Station on the Minato Mirai Line and turn to the right, you will immediately see the entrance.
This building has a total of four floors, with the reception and museum shop on the first floor, the Yokohama Eurasia Memorial Museum on the second floor, the special exhibition room on the third floor, and the permanent exhibition room of the Urban Development Memorial Museum on the fourth floor.
Outside, actual objects such as gas pipes excavated from the ground of the elementary school are on display.
Reception is on the 1st floor, and adults pay 200 yen to enter (* Free for elementary, junior high, and high school students only on Saturdays)
The permanent exhibition room is divided into three areas: ``City Formation Zone,'' ``Citizen Life Zone,'' and ``Yokohama Culture Zone.''
Home appliances and various maps from the Meiji and Taisho eras were on display.
Also, at the time I visited, there was an exhibition based on practical training by university students, and an exhibition using picture postcards. I thought it was amazing how they accepted students and were actively engaged in educational activities.
The last time I went there was a year ago, but I wanted to go again because it exhibits modern Yokohama life from every perspective!

The Yokohama Urban Development Memorial Museum focuses on the early Showa era, when the prototype of the current city of Yokohama was formed, and depicts the history of the development of Yokohama from three aspects: "urban formation," "citizens' lives," and "Yokohama culture." This is a memorial museum where you can trace the history. The museum also exhibits lost modern architecture, a model of a brick sewer manhole from the Meiji era, and gas lamps from the Meiji era.
It is located next to Exit 3 of Nihon-Odori Station on the Minato Mirai Line, and also houses the Yokohama Eurasian Cultural Museum.

[Opening hours]
9:30-17:00 (Ticket sales until 16:30)
【closing day】
Every Monday, year-end and New Year holidays, etc.
[Viewing fee]
General individual: 200 yen
General group: 150 yen (20 or more people, per person)
General elementary and junior high school students: 100 yen
Elementary and junior high school student groups: 80 yen
*Admission fees for special exhibitions and special exhibitions are determined separately.
*Every Saturday, elementary, middle and high school students can watch for free.

It was introduced on TV a while ago, so I decided to take a look.
The first floor was free and there were photographs on display, so I took a look.
In the retro buildings and courtyards, you can see the remains of the city's development, such as gas lamps, gas pipes, brick sewer pipes, and the foundations of gas tanks.

Currently, in order to better understand the city of Yokohama, which has developed rapidly since the opening of the port, we will look at the history of development of Yokohama from the three aspects of ``city formation'', ``citizen life'', and ``Yokohama culture'', mainly during the Showa period. Exhibition facility museum that follows.
Opened in 2003.
The building is a historical building that was built in 1929 (Showa 4) as the office building for the Yokohama Central Telephone Office.
Operated by the Yokohama City Furusato History Foundation, a public interest incorporated foundation.
It is very convenient as it is directly connected to Nihon-Odori Station on the Yokohama Rapid Railway Minatomirai Line.

Admission was free at Hama Fest, so
I went in. Photography was prohibited here.
There is a wealth of materials on display, especially maps.
It had been enhanced. Deeper history of reclamation and reclamation
It will help you know.

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-2-1 Minatomirai, Nishi Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 220-0012, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Landmark Tower

reviews.text:
It was already dark when we got to the tower.  We were able to walk right in to the ticket counter, buy a ticket and walk right on to the elevator.

This elevator - is the fastest one in Japan. It's a 40 second ride to the top!

Once at the top, there were not many people up there.  The snack bar was still open, so we bought some ice cream.  The gift shop had closed down for the day - so no souvenirs from the top!

@kplusds

I felt at home in Yokohama. In my honest and personal opinion, this city is way better than Tokyo. The malls newer and lesser people. Landmark Tower is fancy... it has restos, high end shops and nearby tourist spots make scenic views from this vantage point. Best of all, parking was wide. 👍

Superb centrally located hotel within the Yokohama bay area, surrounded by many shopping areas and entertainment areas.
The hotel itself is what you would expect from a 5 star rated accommodation.
The rooms are large and ultra clean. The staff are very attentive and courteous but the main advantage of this hotel over all the other hotels is the view.
The hotel is the second tallest building in Japan and the hotel rooms begin on the 60th floor, Ours was on the 63rd and we could not fault it. The middle floors are offices and the lower floors are taken up by the massive shopping mall.which includes many restaurants and boutique shops.

I visited solely for views of MT. FUJI, since the Google Maps reviews claimed a “perfect” view with a picture (see below).  “Perfectly clear” skies on online weather reports.  It was completely covered by clouds, and the actual size if it were visible from this distance is actually very small unlike the other reviews’ pictures (TOTAL LIES ON GOOGLE MAPS!!! See below.) :( :( :(

I went to the top of the skyscraper to the observation tower.  It felt weird - clearly this tower is not very popular as I was the only one riding the elevator to the top.

It's inexpensive and the vibe is more chill than the Tokyo Skytree. You can sit at the top and enjoy the view as long as you want.  However, the view is perhaps less interesting if it's a cloudy day.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-18-1 Nakagawachūō, Tsuzuki Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 224-0003, Japan

reviews.text:
Inspiring and knowledgeable museum which walks us to the period of Yokohama from past to the present.
A great history of the people in the past and the development of Yokohama after the war is depicted in an interesting manner.
Definitely a good idea to visit here before going to the Yayoi site nearby. The staff were friendly and there are some lovely pots.
Compact yet comprehensive museum about Yokohama history. Only 1-300 yen. The out door site/park is free
Really maniac musiam. Good place only for local primary school student tour.

Nice overview of the pre-history and early history of the Yokohama area.  Make sure to see the park across the street with reconstructed huts and houses.  Note for English speakers - there is a booklet of translated display signs in addition to the normal brochure.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-1-1 Shinkō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0001, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Red Brick Warehouse 1

reviews.text:
It is a romantic place for walking at night.
I had enjoyed the cool wind from the sea nearby with my friends.
It is also near station, so we can walking around.
I quite curious about the building color, it is beautiful when light up. Nice!
It’s a beautiful sightseeing place at the seaside. There are many nice restaurants and souvenirs shops inside of the building.

The red warehouses are very beautiful. Some of the stores in the buildings are interesting. There are some packaged snacks that look very fancy. But none are enticing enough to be added to the baggage load.

I had no plans of visiting a this place that day, but little did I know that taking a bus right after viewing the moving Gundam would lead me here. As the bus meandered through the city, I noticed a beautiful red brick building with a lot of people and vendors. I decided to step off and explore. It turned out to be a historic site renovated to modern use, I was pleasantly surprised to stumble upon by chance.

Awesome building and great shops!

Presently there are two buildings.  The first building is only occupied on the first floor.  The second building has three stories with the third story occupied by restaurants.

The red brick building has a series of specialty Boutique shops that are not reminiscent of tourist trap.

There are unique shops and artists here as well as many choices for food.

There's on-site parking, and we paid less than $500 yen for about 2 hours.

There's also an observation deck with some sofas and coffee tables where you can sit and rest your feet for a few minutes.

Very comfortable, convenient, and fun.

Highly recommended.

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-8-1 Shinkō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0001, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Cosmo World

reviews.text: Vibrant amusement park perfect for families. Several great rides including the iconic Cosmo Clock 21 Ferris wheel. Fun games, and carnival food. The waterfront location adds to its charm, providing beautiful views, especially at night. Easy to reach from Tokyo.

The ticket system was quite confusing, it’s more like a cash card system. The rides were great and we had a lot of fun with the festival games and arcades as well. The staff were all really kind. We went on a weekday so they were a bit short on staff. Location is very convenient and the rides were good for both kids and adults.

Fun place to come for people of all ages.  Nice mix of rides for little children, teenagers, and adults.  It was a chilly evening, so not many people were getting on the water rides, but they were still opening.  There's also amusement games, shops, and a few places to eat.  For the rides, you purchase the tickets at the central ticketing station.  There was a long line for the Ferris Wheel, but only lasted about 30-45 minutes.  It provided a nice view over Yokohama.
The park was cute I just wish the wait for the Ferris wheel wasn't over two hours. We did however ride the cable car over and back from the train station which was fun and pretty to see.

Riding on the Ferris wheel and the Roller Coaster does take a very long waiting time because there’s a lot of people who wants to get on as well. But there are several other things to do and try. While you there
So i did the 5 star for the experience.

data.formatted_address: Hakkeijima, Kanazawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 236-0006, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Hakkeijima Sea Paradise

reviews.text:
We went first during the week on a regular week day and enjoyed it enough to buy the year pass and have been back again on the weekend. Neither times was it crazy busy and most areas just had a 20-30 minute wait.

It’s is starting to show its age a little and lots of the rides and features that were here 10 years ago have gone and not been replaced. But there’s still plenty left to enjoy.

There are no shows until march and rides have days off for maintenance so please check the website for the schedule. it's easy to use and helps make an informed decision of when to go.

you really want to get at least the full day pass as you'll save money after going to only two places  and two rides.

There are lots of free mini hands on and close up talks throughout the day and paid ones as well.

The food court was surprisingly good with a wide range of choices.

The roller coaster, pirate and water rapids are fun little rides for all and theres a small soft play for under 9s.

plenty to do, even if you arrive at 10am when it opens (you can arrive beforehand to get tickets and the theme park rides open from 11-
am) you still wont be able to do everything in a day.

summary: despite showing its age. it is well worth going for a family day out. make sure you get the full day pass.

Went here during Golden Week and the crowd was surprisingly manageable. Some highlights are the sardines illusion show and the marine mammals show. You can see tanks and dolphin shows anywhere, but with musical and graphic accompaniment, these were emotionally moving and made me fall absolutely in love with the animals there. With these and everything else Sea Paradise has to offer, like the roller coaster, opportunity to play catch with dolphins, and a unique pearl-harvesting souvenir option (paid separately from a Day or Vacation Pass) I definitely think it's super worth the trip to Yokohama. It was really an unforgettable experience.

My  son loved it. You go from one lab to another. They do have nice displays.

I’ll recommend to go there early morning. You can eat on the way to the park. You can either do a half day and only the aquarium or whole day either way the rides. Better to take the day pass. Less hassle. Otherwise you need to pay for each rides thru the internet.

The Sea Paradise alone is an island filled with food and attractions. Got confused when I first came here, between Sea Paradise and Aqua Museum (which was their aquarium). Will definitely take the whole day if you planned to take the rides and explore the area.

I went during g the animal crossing event, however the place itself was amazing, you can upgrade your ticket to go on the adventure rides inside the aquarium which seems like a good idea, but I didn’t have enough time haha , was great fun

reviews.text:
A great place to have have with friends on a day out. Will totally recommend this place and come back here again!

We did Adventure Course and it was extremely fun!
The fee was not so pricey for the fun we experienced. The place was foreign friendly with  English speaking staff.

Will totally recommend and come back here again to try other courses!

Great place to get a safe yet adventurous experience.

I and my husband along with my 7 year old did the trial course which consisted of 4 stages and was really exciting and entertaining for all of us. It was total of 1 hour in the trial course alone. simple yet exciting.

there are more adventure trails available but kids less than 140cm are not allowed in those trails.

- Situated in the zurasia inside the Yokohama zoological place,
-  A small food truck park and clean restrooms available.
- Parking available (paid)

Overall - 5/5 for a safe adventure experience.

Wonderful place to enjoy some thrilling adventures. I tried such kind of place for the first time, I thoroughly enjoyed the adventure course. It seemed a bit difficult in start, but with time it became super fun and exciting. A recommended place to enjoy your weekend with friends or partner. Make sure, it is not raining on your visit day.

We had the beat time here we did thw hardest course it took us a little under 2 hours to complete but it's definitely worth it! Its a great workout lots of upper body activities if ypu jave a phobia of heights it may not be for you but definitely an awesome place
Great customer service. Different levels of difficulty.  For a first timer I found it very easy. Zip lines at the end of each course. Toilet amenities present. Not too busy.

data.formatted_address: 700 Narachō, Aoba Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 227-0036, Japan
data.name: Kodomonokuni

reviews.text: It’s exactly as its name - “Kodomo no kuni” -> Children’s Country!! So so so much fun for not only kids, but family, adults alike! It’s probably our favorite non-theme kids park in Japan!! It has multiple large fun playgrounds for kids of all ages, amazing views, huge open space for all kinds of fun free-style activities, petting zoo (you could even milk a cow or get a pony ride!), one of the longest roller slides in the Tokyo/Yokohama area (1.15km), different interesting car/bike rides, free performances, and kid-oriented craft booths on the weekends as well. The food inside the park is also amazing at the different restaurants, unexpectedly delicious and high quality for a kids park! Highly recommended their soft serve ice cream, which is made from the milk from the cows at the park!

Welcome to KODOMONOKUNI (Children’s Land) Theme Park, Kanagawa, Japan!
This guide is crafted to help future visitors make the most of their trip to this delightful destination, based on a visitor’s experience in April 2024.


KODOMONOKUNI is a vast playground located in Yokohama City. Upon arrival, be prepared for a bit of a walk from the parking area. If you’re visiting with children, bringing a stroller or a cart can be a lifesaver for the trek ahead.


The park features a circular path with athletic play equipment spaced every 10-20 meters, ensuring that children have a variety of activities to enjoy without getting bored. The presence of a small stream, perfect for water play, adds to the charm, offering a refreshing respite during the summer months. While it’s unclear if the stream is man-made or natural, it’s a hit with the kids either way.


KODOMONOKUNI is not just about play; it also houses a zoo, a pool, and leisure facilities with plenty of playground equipment. A visit to the livestock farm managed by Snow Brand is a must, where you can try the special Sungreen milk and ice cream.


The park is open from 9:30 AM to 4:30 PM, with last entry at 3:30 PM. During August, the hours extend to 5:00 PM1.
Admission fees are 600 JPY for adults, 200 JPY for elementary/junior high school students, and 100 JPY for children aged 3 and above1.
Parking is available with a fee of 1,000 JPY per day for cars1.


Plan to stay for at least 120 minutes to fully enjoy the park1.
Bring a picnic to enjoy amidst the greenery, or indulge in the park’s specialty products.
Enjoy your visit to KODOMONOKUNI, where fun and adventure await for the whole family!

My husband used to come here when he was a little kid! Can’t believe we have brought our kids here now!
Great and spacious place for kids to have fun. Well-maintained facilities.
There are different kinds of animals for kids to get close to, like horse, cow, sheep, swan.
The milky ice cream is a must try.
It’s nice that there is a canteen near the main entrance! We had a lunch there before going back home.

I recently had the pleasure of visiting the most amazing kids' playground park, and let me tell you, it was an absolute dream come true for the little ones (and even the grown-ups!). This place is truly a haven of joy and endless entertainment.

The first thing that caught my eye was the incredible variety of slides. From twisty-turny spirals to exhilarating straight drops, the kids were spoiled for choice. Each slide brought laughter and squeals of delight, and the safety measures put my mind at ease.

But that's not all! The park boasts a vast playing area, allowing children to run around and explore to their heart's content. The addition of water play made it even more enjoyable on those hot summer days. The splash of water and gleeful giggles filled the air, creating an atmosphere of pure joy.

As if that weren't enough, there is a small zoo nestled within the park. Kids can get up close and personal with friendly animals, fostering a sense of wonder and a love for nature. The caretakers were knowledgeable and patient, making the experience both educational and delightful.

One of the highlights for me was the small pond where kids can ride boats. It was such a charming sight to see little captains steering their vessels through the calm waters. The sense of adventure and imagination was palpable, and it brought back nostalgic memories of my own childhood.

What truly impressed me was the train-like bus that takes you around the park. For a minimal fee, you can hop aboard and enjoy a leisurely tour. It's a convenient and fun way to explore every nook and cranny of this expansive wonderland.

And let's not forget about the mouthwatering ice cream! There's a delightful selection of flavors, and I couldn't resist treating myself to a scoop. The creamy goodness provided the perfect refresher, and it was the cherry on top of an already fantastic experience.

In conclusion, Kodomo no kuni is an absolute gem. With its array of slides, expansive playing area, water play, small zoo, boat rides, train-like bus, and delicious ice cream, it's a one-stop destination for endless fun and adventure. I highly recommend visiting this place, as it promises to create unforgettable memories for kids of all ages.

Fun outdoor adventure park for children. Very large and spread out which is nice. Cheap to get in but you need to pay for the various attractions. Lots of things to do including pony rides, small petting zoo area, pedal boats, suspension bridge, large roller slide, farm animals, tandem bikes and lots more. Make sure to bring cash for all the attractions.

data.formatted_address: 1 Chome-1 Shinko, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0001, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Red Brick Warehouse

reviews.text:
Recommended to visit on weekdays - on the weekend would be too crowded but most activity and outdoor exhibit held on weekends. The shop was great and the restaurants were so good variety. There is a Disney theme restaurant upstairs.
The park nearby was very relaxing.

This place is a must visit if you’re in Yokohama. There are so many interesting shops and restaurants here that you could easily spend an entire day here. They have a few spots where you can sit and relax but it’s gets crowded at times so it can be hard to find an open seat. I especially like to sit on the balcony. They do have the history of this place on the wall in smaller building, be sure to check it it’s unique history. I think there’s something for everyone here. Be sure to check their website for information about different events they have during the year.

A great shopping experience awaits those who have walked from Yokohama station, a closer station or an even closer cruise ship.
There are plenty of small concessions in the two buildings providing locals and tourists alike with goods to purchase.
The restaurants were busy and the queues for the rest rooms were long, but an enjoyable day nonetheless.
One of only a few brick built buildings in Yokohama and definitely worth a visit.

A place with its unique identity that can definitely uplift anyone’s mood without a doubt. The positive vibes flowing throughout the ambience and instantly bring joy to anyone who enters the radius within Yokohama Red Brick Warehouse. It’s no surprise to spend the most part of your day strolling along, pausing to take some pictures and even take a long moment to enjoy the blooms, the fresh air, the sea breeze from nearby port or even looking up to see bits of various species navigating their way above this wonderful place. May the bliss, joy and vibrancy, flow of joy always remain with this top tourist attractions in Yokohama! 🥰

A square and a building where you can see the open port. The Yokohama dock in front of it is wonderful, and it is also a place where you can see landmark towers and skyscrapers. Omega of Yokohama Tourism

reviews.text: I went to the Sky Garden on a Thursday immediately when it opened. There was barely anybody there and it was perfect for me and my special lady to get a complete scoop of the Amazing scenery of Yokohama. They even have a food bar that serves delicious snacks and very tasty ice cream. I recommend getting the Vanilla and the Cider ice cream mixed it’s very delicious. Overall I give the Sky Garden 5/5 it’s definitely worth it . The Weekends get very crowded but it’s still worth it.

Went to the Landmark Sky Garden on a Tuesday mid day. There was no line, however it was a pretty cloudy day. If I were to do it again, I would plan to come on a clear day, and I would try to make it happen at the end of the day. I would try and catch the sunset hour so you can see the skyline during the day, catch the sunset and then watch the city scape light up at night! The view is pretty spectacular, but it is a bit pricy.

Great observatory. I went mid day during a weekend and it wasn't crowded at all. Tickets are about half the price for the tokyo sky tree but the view was still impressive. Unfortunately I went at the start of summer so visibility wasn't good due to the haze. If you want to see mt fuji well  go in autumn, winter or early spring.

I visited solely for views of MT. FUJI, since the Google Maps reviews claimed a “perfect” view with a picture (see below).  “Perfectly clear” skies on online weather reports.  It was completely covered by clouds, and the actual size if it were visible from this distance is actually very small unlike the other reviews’ pictures (TOTAL LIES ON GOOGLE MAPS!!! See below.) :( :( :(

Amazing! The 69th floor observation deck offers a stunning 360 degree view of Yokohama for only Y1000 per adult. There is also a cafe, a store, bathrooms, and plenty of chairs up there to make your stay comfortable.

I'm glad I decided to go here on a whim on a weekday evening. I didn't buy tickets in advanced, but there was basically no line / wait times. They take Visa / Mastercard so buying the ticket was straightforward

data.formatted_address: 114 Yamatechō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0862, Japan
data.name: Harbor View Park Observatory

reviews.text:
The Harbor View Park Observatory (港の見える丘公園 展望台) offers visitors a stunning vantage point to admire the scenic beauty of the harbor and surrounding landscapes. Situated atop a hill, this observatory provides panoramic views of the bustling port, serene waters, and distant horizon.

From the observatory, visitors can take in the dynamic activity of the harbor, with ships coming and going against the backdrop of the city skyline. Whether it's watching the sunrise over the water or enjoying the twinkling lights of the harbor at night, the Observatory provides a memorable experience for visitors of all ages.

With its peaceful atmosphere and breathtaking views, the Harbor View Park Observatory is an ideal destination for nature lovers, photographers, and anyone seeking a moment of tranquility amidst the vibrant energy of the city.

Beautiful and serene. Keep in mind for elderly or hot weather, if you're coming from the west side there are a few flights of stairs. Walking up was totally worth the view and there's places to rest in between if needed.
Amazing view of the city and bridge. I really recommend visiting at sunset/night as it looks even more spectacular.

I love the vibe in this park, so calm and relaxing, and amazing views of Yokohama, I love how do they look the lighthouse and also you can even watch Gundam Factory, it's a nice place to have a walk and see beautiful landscapes, it also have a British garden with many different king of flowers.
Great view and has beautiful rose garden(May 2nd).

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒220-8401 Kanagawa, Yokohama, Nishi Ward, Minatomirai, 3-chōme−3−１ 三菱重工横浜ビル
data.name: Mitsubishi Minatomirai Industrial Museum

reviews.text: I came here to spend the morning after arriving Japan and it is a hidden gem in Yokohama.  Very detailed history of Mitsubishi and it’s vision to provide better and more resilient energy options to the mankind.  I enjoyed the hour I spent, really good.

Interesting museum which showcases the different industrial business units of the Mitsubishi Heavy Industries conglomerate group. It is also catered for kids to learn about science and the environment as well.

Visited in May 2023.
For 500 yen, I think it is rather small. I didn't know Mitsubishi produced such a vast array of things though, so it's actually a little bit bigger than my initial expectation.

We went during goldenweek and arrived 9:55am before opening. But it was not as busy as we thought.

It’s a fairly small museum and although some exhibits where not in operation due to Covid measures (touching and pushing buttons), it was still an interesting exhibition. Both for us adults and for the kids.

My daughter especially enjoyed the space projection. She asked a lot of questions because the explanations are a harder to understand for kids.
She can read Japanese but the explanations are too technical for kids to understand.
This is a common problem with those kind of museums. Maybe a kids guide could be added in the future.
They do have a really cool retro mid century modern inspired wallpaper about the history of aviation. It’s pretty and key information is added throughout in both Japanese and English. This would be a great add to the souvenir shop if not already available.

Also for some reason the souvenir shop wasn’t open which my daughter was looking forward to as she’s super into space stuff.

We spend about an hour inside and recommend a visit of you like space, submarines and energy related stuff.
A MHI's company promotion exhibition center. There are so many modern displays and exhibitions. Kids can definitely enjoy for a half day at least. Entrance fee is 500 yen.

data.formatted_address: Yamashitacho, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Chinatown

reviews.text: Subway took me straight to the entrance.   Lots of places to eat.  I found the famous place where they sold the buns that looked like cute animals.  No wait time.  It was a hot day, though.  So it will be very hot walking down the street during the summer.  Plan accordingly.

We wanted to enjoy and try some Chinese food in Japan. I really enjoy walking around and seeing so much food. There’s many all you can eat places and a lot of tanhulu. Make sure you have water and keep yourself hydrated. There’s many beautiful monuments to look at and street food! Definitely recommend you coming here and enjoy the culture/food.

OMG We came here during Golden Week on a day trip to Yokohama, planned to get some dinner here....and it was super busy and crowded...there were a lot of dancing dragons and crouching tigers outside the Chinese restaurants especially the ones with Republic of China flags...there was a celebration happening and people were dropping firecrackers....absolutely mindblown by the hustle and bustle here at Yokohama Chinatown...lots of good food too!!! Highly recommended!

Absolutely must come during dusk and evening. The place is light up like a carnival in such a beautiful way. Largest Chinatown in Japan and it shows. Sprawls through a good portion of Yokohama. Highly recommend spending some time down there even if you’re not hungry (you’ll eventually get hungry seeing all the great food on display). If you can catch it on a rainy day (like I did) even better.

While China Town in Yokohama offers a wide variety of dishes to choose from, my family and I found it to be a bit too crowded for our liking. Navigating through the bustling streets was a challenge, especially with young children in tow. However, I must admit, the diverse selection of dishes available was impressive. If you don't mind crowds and enjoy exploring different cuisines, China Town is worth a visit. Just be prepared for the hustle and bustle!

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-200 Sakuragichō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0062, Japan
data.name: YOKOHAMA AIR CABIN Sakuragicho Station

reviews.text: This was a great way to see the sunset over Yokohama. It was so pretty. It’s a short 5 minute ride from the Red Brick area to the other side and back. You can get round trip or one way tickets. There is a train station right there and parking near by.

It was close to sunset when I strolled by Yokohama Air Cabin, I was truly fascinated by these well paced cabins floating above me, ferrying its passengers from one end to another, enabling the passengers with Birds Eye’s view to enjoy such lovely sunset view across the vicinity of Yokohama Bay. Occasionally I would lift my head up to look at these cabins while at the same time feeling the joy around with people walking, laughing and having wonderful moments with their loved ones. My next trip would be taking a “float” in one of this cabin and feel the difference compared to walking on the path, as I believe it must have been a beautiful and memorable Yokohama experience for me.

¥1800 for 2-way ride

Be mindful of their operation hours, especially for the return ride. There could be long lines during weekends.

Ride was few minutes long, but if you come alone, you'll have the cabin to yourself! 🤗 They don't let people who were not together share a cabin. 👍🏻

/travelspeedx

The nice view is breathtakingly beautiful, although it is such a short ride, we take the cable from Sakuragicho station. I suggest taking a one-way ticket and then walking back for it is not that far.

Tired of walking? My tourist feet were toast. The air cabin was so nice and clean. I was able to enjoy beautiful views of Yokohama and rest my plantar fasciitis. It’s a deal for a one way ticket of 1000Yen! No line at 430PM!

data.formatted_address: 3-chōme-1-53 Takigashira, Isogo Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 235-0012, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Tram Museum

reviews.text: Nice, small museum in Yokohoma tracing the history of the street cars (trams) in the city. Many street cars remain in the building and you can walk on and sit in all of them. Plenty of history in the museum regarding their operations and development. A few activities for kids with some free simulators and two nice model train layouts. The price is cheap, only 300 yen and worth an hour or two. They do have a few eating tables and vending machines if you need a snack. All in Japanese, so be prepared to translate if you're not fluent.

Quite a collection of actual trams used to run in yokohama, but lots of kids messing and chasing each other around (their mothers? just looked on without asking them to behave), sigh... Could be a nice museum, if with better management and some self-discipline, this is now just been downgraded to a playground.
Wonderful place! Not so touristy and well known. Lovely to see the old street cars and learn about Yokohama’s history. Quite a few families with young children were there. Hidden gem in Yokohama!

It was an wonderful experience to  know the history of public transpiration of Yokohama. Even though the exhibition area is small the exhibit indulge us and take us back to the past. We can see miniature Yokohama with automated transportation.

Accidentally found this museum when I am looking around Negishi Park. I took a bus to there, so I entitle 100yen discount from 300 yen to 200yen (300yen still cheap relatively).
It is a must visit museum in Yokohama. Can take bus 21 from Sakuragicho Station.

data.formatted_address: Yokohamakoen, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0022, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Park

reviews.text: The beauty of Yokohama Park is well known as it is full of blooms all year round, cherry blossoms and tulips can be seen at the park the minute you walked in the vicinity. Yokohama stadium is located just a stone throw away. The entire park is enveloped with blissful joy as we look up to enjoy the Hanami while we bend down to zoom our view and admire the colourful tulips, red, purple, yellow, pink, just name it, you’ll have it. I spent a good half of my morning just sit around from bench to bench, enjoying the breeze on a beautiful spring weekend! It’s no wonder I started to see crowds after 9am onwards. Joyful look in adults and young toddlers or even silver generations alike and our furry buddies, immersing themselves in a wonderful morning during this spring! Take a stroll down the park and feel the morning joy yourself.

I saw a Baystars game for the first time, and it was a lot of fun! The crowd had different chants for each player. Bento, beer, and snacks are available for purchase as well as jerseys, hats, and lots of cute baystars swag. Definitely recommend checking out a game if you are in the area!
The tulips were gorgeous!! I truly appreciate how many different kinds they plant and you can tell they are well cared for.
Great baseball stadium. Been here a few times. Great Baystars shop outside the stadium. Everything you could want and more.
If you wish to enjoy your day or are fond of seaside environment. Then this is the place to check out

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-14-21 Shinyokohama, Kohoku Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 222-0033, Japan
data.name: Shin-Yokohama Ramen Museum

reviews.text: Honestly, the Shin-Yokohama Ramen Museum was a bit of a letdown. If you're looking for an exceptional ramen experience, this isn't the place, especially when Tokyo has so many fantastic options. The ramen here was just average and overpriced compared to other spots I've tried. The ambiance and decor were cool, but gastronomically, it didn't offer anything special.

Many good ramen stores in lower floor. Don't be confused with the cup noodles museum. This place had better "making your own cup noodles" You can upload your own image as the cover of the cup noodles.
This place give you an old time feeling.

ATTENTION, HELPFUL REVIEW FOR COUPLES!
as tourists we of course also had the ramen museum on our list, we were there a little after 12:00, no people anywhere, we were a little afraid that it was closed, but it wasn't, hardly anyone inside either. The historical facts were very interesting, the interior gave us a glimpse into the past. Unfortunately, we encountered one very unpleasant thing, when my husband and I wanted to have ramen like everyone else, we thought we would try at least two restaurants to have more of an experience. when we came to the first machine to order, we paid and a ticket fell out, we go on, we sit down, we order and suddenly we were told that if each of us does not order, we will not get food and that neither of us can share food … So we dealt with it quite a bit, as we absolutely did not understand why they did not want to give us the food that we had already paid for… my husband finally declared that he would not give me the food and would eat it himself, but still they refused to serve us , saying that either we all order food, or we won't get a single one. It upset us a lot, because a lot of couples, when they go somewhere to taste something, have one meal. I note that it was half empty, so it couldn't have been due to a lack of seats either. So very upset we got our money back and walked away completely amazed at what had happened.

+
interesting interior and historical facts

-
unfortunately, the interior of the apartment was badly damaged and everything was repaired very badly with tape

This was such a cool experience. Not only my did we get to learn about ramen we got to get custom ramen bowls made that we could take home.

To make a custom bowl it’s very easy. You scan the QR code and follow the steps. You can use there images or upload your own from your phone. These make good gifts too.

There was a parking garage attached to the museum and they valid your parking ticket for part of the time.

Very reasonable ticket entry (¥450 adults), inside there, few Ramen places that you can choose ( line up and pay upfront). A unique place, feels like an old Japanese town. You can also make your own cup noodles and choose your own toppings.

data.formatted_address: 1 Daikokufutō, Tsurumi Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 230-0054, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Bay Bridge Skywalk

reviews.text:
Excellent place for short timers. It's free, the binoculars are free as well. Beautiful bridge view, minatomirai view, can sea light house, can see people enjoying their ⛵ yacht. People fishing there, what else not.

Parking is there, parking free too. No crowd, simple go there relax.
There is no entrance fee, and yet the facilities  are clean, and the view of the coast is breathtaking, especially during sunset.

You can see the entire Yokohama from this bridge, and it is best to view it at sunset. However, it is pretty anytime of the day. All the binoculars here are free too, and there are no entrance fees or parking fees. Highly recommended for photos and sightseeing in general.
Wonderful view 😍

This is a facility where you can enjoy the view from the Bay Bridge.Of course, you can also learn about the structure and history of the bridge. You can see Minato Mirai from a different angle than usual, and if the weather is good, you can also see Mt. Fuji in the background. If you want to take photos that include Mt. Fuji, I think it would be best to take a sunny day in winter when the air is clear.
Parking is free, and when I was taking pictures on my bike, the guide told me a lot of things.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-1 Kaigandōri, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0002, Japan
data.name: Elephant's Nose Breakwater

reviews.text: Also known as the elephant breakwater due to its shape. It's more than a 100 years old. Look out for a historic photo of the breakwater on display.
Lovely view. Easily accessible by bus and private vehicle. Evening time is recommended.
A water breaker supposedly looks like the elephant nose.
Fantastic place for taking photos of Yokohama's skyline. It's clean, spacious and easy to find. Highly recommended!
A nice scenic spot. It wasn't too windy here but the sun was definitely beating down. This was the only spot in the entire two weeks we were in Japan that I got a sunburn!!

data.formatted_address: 145 Yamashitachō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Hakurankan

reviews.text: It said its an exhibit with free entry but it's really a shopping and food mall. 2nd level is a instant noodle place where you can see how they make instant noodle and buy them with a price tag of 500 Yen.  Don't try the skill testers, it's a money eater.
One of the most popular souvenir stores in this area.
Great pork bun filling!
Nik naks and lots of panda items. Some items reasonably priced, others not.
Good place for souvenirs and snacks. Some items are overpriced

data.formatted_address: 1175-1 Kamishiranechō, Asahi Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 241-0001, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Zoological Gardens “Zoorasia”

reviews.text:
First, allow me to start on a positive note: Asian Tropical Forest is a well-maintained and clean zoo with many family-friendly amenities and picnic spaces. They boast a large variety of animals. HOWEVER... Some enclosures for larger mammals and birds with flight capabilities are disappointingly small for animals that naturally roam. Tama Zoo sets a commendable example by striving to create more natural and explorable environments for its larger animals.

It was particularly disheartening to see Asian Tropical Forest, given the vast land they have, opt for large parks, play areas, and expansive grassy fields for humans instead of larger enclosures for the animals. I believe the welfare of the animals should always take precedence, which I didn't feel was fully considered given their land use. For instance, there's a large field with a fake elephant enjoying a massive enclosure while the two real elephants share a cramped space (See in my pictures for an example).

I remain hopeful that as laws concerning animal welfare align more closely with global standards and with the resources available to them, Asian Tropical Forest will prioritize creating more animal-friendly environments.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ #Recommend

- Clean zoo
- Clean toilet
- Good atmosphere
- Friendly staff
- Food and drinks shop available
- Most animals are take rest when cold weather
- Clean walkway

🐫🦙🦮🦬🦍🐪🦧🐆🦘

A Great Way to Spend time with family and friends here.

A great zoo with many animals you would not expect in Colorado, like tigers, elephants, giraffes, and many from warmer climates.

They also had penguins and grizzly bears. All habitats were educational and the overall scenery was great. Plenty of food options, we had pizza and meatballs, that can fill the youngest to oldest taste desires. All staff are willing to help and educate about the animals they are working with. A definite must for families with younger children, or those whom like getting some excise, fresh air, and see interesting animals.

Great experience for kids. Feels like a jungle safari than visiting a zoo.  I was impressed by how elaborately the facility was built. The shade, rest area, and restrooms are clean and conveniently located at a short walk away. The roads are well-maintained and the paths are wide, making it easy to navigate even with strollers and wheelchairs.

Big place and a great environment for animals. If you come from Tokyo you need to take the train and get on the bus to the zoo. Not various kinds of animals. If you love to walk you will enjoy it here.

You can wait in line to get tickets, If you can’t wait. You can get tickets using your Suica card and you don’t have to wait in line for that.
Smooth experience.
Had mad fun, Hope you do too…

data.formatted_address: 97 Yamashitachō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Daisekai

reviews.text: Great building for an afternoon of entertainment. The trick Art museum is fun, the food stalls outside are tasty. Have to come back for the chocolate store and Dr. Fish
This place has some rooms to take pictures. It’s not anything special really.
Theres a trick art museum inside its lots of fun, then a chocolate shop on the 1st floor

Not a bad place to go for a fish doctor foot exfoliation, some souvenirs of Japan, entertainment with several floors of optical illusions, and a small chocolate factory. A bit more than the usual department store.

Check out the Trick Art Museum! It is one of the coolest things I have ever experienced. It's 4 floors of different optical illusions and hands on exhibits. There a so many photo opportunities inside and it's only 1,000 yen which I find extremely worth the price. One of the floors has a laser light show with music and cool visual effects and there are so many things to experience inside. A good hour and a half of goofing around. This place is very good for kids and families and extremely fun!

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒231-0023 Kanagawa, Yokohama, Naka Ward, Yamashitachō, １ シルクセンタ 2階
data.name: Silk Museum

reviews.text: If you're interested in textiles I would definitely recommend this museum. Really informative with some stunning pieces and even some live silk larvae ! I enjoyed trying the weaving loom. Has information in English as well as Japanese.

There you can be informative for the silk types, the process of extracting it, the Japanese evolvement of the silk industry. Additionally, you can experience how to use it to make texture with mixing of two colors. Also, samples of historical Japanese clothes are there. Apart from clothes, you can find different usages of the silk in the Japanese industries.
See silk worms and also how the silk is taken out of cocoon.

Super informative about the knowledge of silk. You can also try the sewing machine under the guidance of the staff there. May be a little bit too niche for most visitors however.

Would like to add photos of the museum for this review but 99% of the artifacts in the museum were not permitted for photography.
Very interesting place to visit. Tells and shows how silk is taken from the cacoon of the silk worm as well as the life cycle of the worm..

data.formatted_address: 2 Takarachō, Kanagawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 221-0023, Japan
data.name: Nissan Engine Museum

reviews.text: My experience was really amazing. They offer us an inside factory tour also. Only on the 1st floor, you are allowed to capture pictures. Others you can not. 1st they will give an introductory presentation to explain the journey of Nissan car. Then followed by the floor tour. You can not take pictures there. But as a foreigner, I felt difficulties because they were explaining in Japanese 🥲. They have English on their board but I couldn't understand what they were saying. Then they gave an inside factory tour also. They arranged a minibus and took you inside the factory where you can observe the making of a car. 80 robots are working inside and lots of noise of course. The whole tour was really safe as they maintained safety procedures always. If you are near Yokohama and are interested in automobile manufacturing, you can give a visit

Great museum, however I must warn those with a passing interest in cars that this is fairly Niche. It is literally just engines and a little bit of history of Nissan. If this sounds up your street, then great! But I could see non-petrol heads finding it very tedious.

I enjoyed it however!

Just to add, it isn't well signposted that most of the stuff is on the upper floor (1st to those in the UK, 2F in Japan or to the US) so make sure not to miss that!

Only open on the weekdays, this museum was a cool little trek. Fair warning: it is a 15-20 walk from the nearest train station in a clean and sort of industrial area. The guard at the gate immediately knew we were there for the museum.  Kinda happy to see his smile after walking in the heat. 2 stories building, and almost all their iconic engines and history inside. There is a small vending machine with some gifts to purchase. After we walked back the way we came. It was a fun and different thing to do.

It was a bit of a trek to get too.
About 1hr 20 mins from Shinjuku. About 45 mins of content in the museum. Was hoping for a bit more given the trek. Staff were very friendly. Free to enter !
Could've had a bit better signage on the outside, but it's really awesome for all (not only) car and Nissan enthusiasts.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒220-0011 Kanagawa, Yokohama, Nishi Ward, Takashima, 1-chōme−1−２, YOKOHAMA MITSUI BUILDING, 2F
data.name: Hara Model Railway Museum

reviews.text: The best miniature museum on Japan!  The diorama not only contains trains,  but countless references to art, modern and old, and also told a lot of short stories.  The staff were super friendly,  and tried their best to translate to English for us!   The other information and displays were great also!!

It was a fun place to learn about trains. One of the guide is so passionate that he kept sharing with us. Its quiet on a Thursday noon time. The kids had fun trying to find the items that were on the brochure.

Too bad that they don't have a souvenir shop after covid. Tickets have to be bought on level 1 from the convenience store. Nothing too inconvenient really.

It's the private collection of a guy whose name I forgot. When he was younger, he travelled different countries to take pics and vids of trains. There are exhibits about that. Anyway, the model train diorama is in g-gauge, or 1-gauge (45mm track width), so the diorama is pretty big. About the size of a tennis court. It depicts an european scenery with a small town, a few mountains and a lot of railway related stuff. There are plenty of seats to have a rest and just enjoy the trains going round and round. They have a lot of German trains running, also french and American. The trains also change (there is a timetable, of course). A nice guy is talking to the guests and explains a lot of stuff. The lighting was really good, changed from day to night every few minutes. There's also a smaller HO-gauge diorama depicting Yokohama. You have to buy the tickets in advance. Easiest way is to get them at the convenient store (the touch screen machine where you can buy almost anything online). I spent a couple of hours there and have good memories.

A great little museum to visit if you or your child likes trains the guide was very helpful and provided information to us in English, and pointed out many parts of the train diorama to us to make sure we were included. Excellent!

American Family visiting.  Be sure to buy your tickets in advance.  There is a Family mart on the first floor where you can use a machine to purchase.  I didn't purchase in advance and was lucky to be in while it was slow so a museum staffer came down and helped me purchase.  Very friendly.

Very little English spoken but the exhibits have some English to help and there is a QR guide (I didn't use).  Lots of trains on display from around the world as well as the history of the museums namesake.  It was very cool.  Recommend Google Translate to help where needed.  The hardest part for non Japanese speakers would likely be the ticket purchase.  Tickets are purchased for specific time slots so if they are busy and you just walk up, they may not have tickets but the place was very slow when we visited.

The diorama room was amazing with different sets of trains running at different times.  Lighting goes through the cycle of the day.  One staffer in this room was very enthusiastic explaining the diorama and all the hidden things and art you can find in it.  He used a translator with great success to explain things.

A slow walk through the exhibits you spend probably about an hour going around (less with impatient kids, more for the enthusiast who wants to take in every detail of the trains).  Highly recommended and a fun visit.  A little on the high side for tickets however there is no souvenir shop so the price kinda evens out.  Loved it and would visit again.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒231-0001 Kanagawa, Yokohama, Naka Ward, Shinkō, 2-chōme−3−１ 2階
data.name: Japanese Overseas Migration Museum

reviews.text:
Very interesting look into the migration habits of the Japanese, learnt some new things and entry was free which was nice.
Adam 34 🇬🇧

This is a excellent museum explaining the last 140 yrs of Japanese migration covering the USA
, Hawaii and South American experience in some depth.
I spent 45 reading most of the narratives.  They are in English and well as I think Portuguese and Spanish translations.  lots of great photos, artefacts and video memories.  Highly recommended.
It’s a pretty cool and modern building and it’s free to enter and see the museum. It’s managed by Jica and everything is so organized and impressive that it’s too good to be free.

Didn’t plan visiting the centre at all (as I I didn’t even know it’s existence) but we were pleasantly surprised when we accidentally bumped in there.

Pretty rich history on migration from Japan since two decades ago. It touched on assimilation and how to preserve the root for the next generations. All very thoughtfully made.
This museum is an undiscovered gem having a broad story to tell with sophisticated displays and artifacts.  I would have liked to stay much longer.

data.formatted_address: 2-chōme-3-4 Shinkō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0001, Japan
data.name: Cup Noodles Museum Yokohama

reviews.text: A fun place to visit.  It was cool learning about the history of cup noodles.  Although I chose not to make my own cup noodle, I could have paid for it and experience no wait time.  If you are a fan of noodles, it's worth a visit.  The video presentation about Momofuku's challenges making cup noodles was fun to watch.

Nice history and details about the famous cup noodles company. There was also a short film in Japanese with English subtitles. I love the positivity from the business model of not giving up, helping the community, and finding solutions, It was a big building but very little inside.
We were done in 1 hour without making our own cup noodle designs. The design area looked fun, though. Lots of people were carrying the clear plastic bag with a cup noodle inside.
It was a nice experience and worth it.
Tip: there is a cool cup noodle visual electrical machine on the outside of the building to see also (facing the main road)

Fun for the whole family who visit the Cup Noodles museum. You get to see and hear the history about Cup Noodles and can even design your own cup and have noodles, seasoning and and toppings added to it to take home in a sealed bag. There is an eating area that you can go into and buy lunch. They are all noodle dishes from several Asian country's that you can try. All of the food we had here was very good and very affordable.

Very educational, inspiring , and fun ! I recommend that you get the "build your own cup noodle" tickets as soon as you can, this was a lot of fun. If you go up to the noodle bar , be aware that these are more like "tastings" so don't expect to get full off one order. Would recommend checking this place out .

We showed up in the evening towards the end of the operating hours and were able to purchase tickets as walk ups.  We were given a time to be at the make your own noodles, which gave us plenty of time to wander through the museum part.
It begins with a film about the history of Cup Noodles which had English subtitles.  It’s a great story of perseverance and ingenuity.  The museum is well spaced out for crowds with many interactive displays for children and adults.
For the making your own Cup Noodle, you do need 500 Yen (in cash) to buy the cup and get started.  You are directed to a child sized table with markers to decorate your cup.  Once  you are done, you go up to the line to have your cup filled with noodles and different toppings.  I used my Google translator at the table to read the different toppings, so I was prepared when I got to that part of the line.  We all stumbled through it, but it was a fun experience!

@kplusds

data.formatted_address: 239-2 Yamatechō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0862, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Museum of Tin Toys

reviews.text:
its a wonderful experience. not a common sight to see anywhere in disneyland or universal studios.
thankful to friend who brought us there.
the creator of TOY STORY got his inspiration from the collection of toys of this museum.
the owner is a very famous japanese personality and has a You Tube. kindly check them.

I visited here 27 years ago.  It is still a great place I like to visit.  They even added a Chritmas Toys area, and a real car garage.
They have set up something like a route 61 1960s drive up road diner.

What a fantastic little museum, worth the trip up hill (there is a bus too), through an area that used to be a foreigners restricted enclave with a view over the bay.

The museum is packed with beautiful tin toys from 19th century through the 50’s/60’s boom period, if you like this sort of thing and even if you don’t know if you do, it’s a great thing to do.

We had one of our bags go missing at the airport on the way home and it had all the postcards I bought at the museum…which are a must…brilliantly done photos of toys placed in real life situations…i emailed the museum and they are trying to help send me some replacements…just lovely people…

So much to look at! Easy to appreciate this amazing collection of tin toys. Staff were very friendly and keen to share interesting facts about the pieces. The shop dog is adorable.the entry price is reasonable if you take time to enjoy looking at the toys. I would take family here when they come to visit. Hint: take the escalator up America Yama Park to cut some of the uphill walk.

A tiny museum crammed full of nostalgia. Well worth the 10 minute walk!

It's a bit difficult to get to: you have to go from Motomachi-Chukagai Station out into and through the American Park and up the hill past the foreign cemetery.

data.formatted_address: 142 Kanazawachō, Kanazawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 236-0015, Japan
data.name: Kanazawa-bunko Museum

reviews.text: The below comment describe everything in detail,nothing much to say.

Mid June 2024
I walked from Kanazawa Bunko Station to Mr. Hojo's ``Kanazawa Bunko.''
Old buildings are not being preserved or recreated.
The materials are stored and displayed in a reinforced concrete building, but it was very interesting.
I'm glad I came to see it.
The admission fee for adults was 250 yen.

Less than 10 minutes walk from Kanazawa Bunko Station.
The exhibits were wonderful, including a chronology and video explanation of Shomyo-ji Temple, valuable letters, and murals from the Kamakura period.
I was satisfied even without going to Kamakura.

I went to the current "Ruins and Images" exhibition. My impression after visiting was that I would like many people to see this exhibit. With the theme of "ruins," national treasures and important cultural properties are collected and exhibited from museums and temples across the country. What's more, you can directly see rare and maniacal paintings, documents, porcelain, and even Buddha's relics that are not usually on permanent display. Paintings from the collections of the National Museums in Kyoto and Nara have been lent to Kanazawa Bunko for this exhibition. The collection of Kanazawa Bunko used to be amazing. It seems that Tokugawa Ieyasu also took Japan's oldest manuscript of the Tale of Genji (Kawachi version), but it has now returned to its original location in Kanazawa Bunko. Additionally, the documents left behind at Shomyo-ji Temple have been designated as national treasures, making me realize once again that it is a valuable facility for Kanagawa Prefecture. I thought it would be a loss if I didn't go to this exhibition, where I could see national treasure-level cultural artifacts in a compact space. Furthermore, the curator's explanation was very easy to understand, and I was able to get a real sense of the flow of history, centering on Kamakura history.

First visit.
There is a tunnel when you go from the Shomyoji temple grounds, so it is a good introduction.
There are exhibits on the 1st and 2nd floors of the museum.
Since it is not large, there are not many exhibits.
It was quiet and there weren't many people visiting, so I was able to enjoy the view in peace.

data.formatted_address: 5-chōme-60 Minaminakadōri, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0006, Japan
data.name: Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Cultural History

reviews.text: The building was the former Yokohama Specie Bank. A place to learn about the history of the Kanagawa Prefecture. You can also enjoy ¥50 discount at the cafe.
The museum was really nice. I learned a lot about the local history however the special exhibition had no english translations at all and my internet did not work.
For 300 yen, this is a great place to go! Great exhibits - down side is not everything has a English translation.

Historical museum that present you various era. In the 3rd floor, there is ancient era exhibition. In the 4th floor, there is pre modern era and in 5th floor there is modern and contemporary area. Closed at 17.00. Nice 👍

A good museum with limited English, Korean, and Chinese translations for written information. While the exhibitions are not a comprehensive retelling of Japanese history, it gives a solid overview and survey of important historical events and lifestyles of ancient peoples living in Japan. This museum may be better suited for individuals with prior knowledge and interest in Japanese history rather than novice or beginner enthusiasts. The museum also features a modest selection of goods and books related to Yokohama and other Japanese history for sale at the gift shop.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒231-0023 Kanagawa, Yokohama, Naka Ward, Yamashitachō, １８ 1F
data.name: Yokohama Doll Museum

reviews.text: The museum is really nice but it’s a bit too pricey if you want to enter the special exhibit which costs ¥1000 + regular entrance fee.

Getting the chance to see dolls from around the world all in one stop is nice. I would add that special exhibitions are also very creative.

Prices(2023):
400 yen entry,
700 - 1000 yen  with special exhibitions.

While the exhibits are simple and easy to peruse, the Doll Museum keeps to the common themes of the use of folks over the centuries to tell stories, bring comfort, and most importantly to help cultural understanding between countries. Fortunately, this is not one of those often creepy clown museums, but instead showcases a variety of interesting designs, labeled by country and region, with some commentary in English, Japanese, and other languages about the history and cultures behind those designs. A very nice way to spend a couple of hours
This museum showcases the history of dolls in Japan and the different per region. It also showcases dolls from around the world.

The Japanese doll section is a master piece.
They have nice documentary as how the dolls are made, worth watching.
Nice doll collection from all over the world.
There was a special exhibit when we went but with extra fees.
Staff is polite and helping.

data.name: Keikyu Museum

reviews.text: Exhibition is interesting, my daughter is very fond of trains and public transport, so I came to this museum.  But I was deeply disappointed with the service, very unfriendly service for foreigners.  You need to make a reservation if you want to get to interesting activities, for example, to drive a high-speed train.  We spent a lot of time in waiting line with the child to find out that it turns out that you need to make a reservation.  What?!
It was fun. Nice city model. And entrance was free. But few stations and kind of small.
Great little meusum. Just check the hours before you go!
Small, with few good exhibits. Not worth a special trip, but nice enough if you should happen to stumble upon it.

Located on the 1st floor of Keikyu Head Office.
Until now, there were three admissions and reservations were required, but except for the first part in the morning, from the second part onward, you can enter without reservation if you go during the admission time.
As expected, the dynamic preservation of Deha 230 is impressive! There was an era of 230 quadruple lines on the Daishi Line!
The diorama is also elaborately made, especially where the Daishi Line intersects with the 409 railroad crossing between Kawasaki and Minatocho, which realistically reproduces the traffic jam.

data.formatted_address: 6-1 Sakaechō, Kanagawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 221-0052, Japan
data.name: Miyagawa Kozan Makuzu Ware Museum

reviews.text: A small museum exhibiting works of a single artist, i. e. interior items such as vases, pots and boxes with intricate decorations. I enjoyed the exhibition very much and spent much time admiring all the tiny details of the items. Each had an entire world on it and can be viewed from different angles.

I came here to see it aired on TV ``Beautiful Titan.''
wonderful!
A potter like a sculptor. How did you create this group of creative works?
Frog, mouse, bird, hawk, crab...
All kinds of animals appeared on the pottery one after another, and it was a series of surprises.
Also, each piece is exquisitely crafted.

Many of Miyagawa Kazan's works are on display at the Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of History (former Yokohama Specie Bank head office, an important cultural property) located on Bashamichi.
If you check before visiting, it's efficient as you can visit two places in one day.
(Photos are OK here, photos are OK at the Prefectural Museum of History)

Located on the east side of the north exit of Yokohama Station on the JR Tokaido Main Line, just past the Yokohama Bay Quarter, this is a small art museum open on Saturdays and Sundays that displays Makuzu ware collected by Dr. Yamamoto. Makuzu ware, also known as Yokohama ware, was created by the first Mr. Koyama Miyagawa in the Meiji period.As an export item for the promotion of industry, very few pieces remained in Japan, but in the late 1950s, Mr. Tetsuto Tanabe bought it back for research purposes. Dr. Yamamoto is now known as the foremost expert on Makuzu ware, and is the second-largest collector after Tetsuto Tanabe. The entrance fee is 800 yen, which is not cheap considering the size of the museum, but based on other people's reviews, it seems that photography is not allowed inside the exhibition rooms, but I checked with the reception staff and it is also on the website. It's worth it because you can take pictures of all points. There is also a museum shop that sells postcards, catalogs, etc., so it is a place I highly recommend checking out.
It seems that because information was lost in the air raids, it became impossible to pass on the technology. His remaining works are excellent. 2023/3/19

It's a great feast for the eyes as you can see the superb technique up close.
You can take photos of the works displayed in the space next to the reception, so I thought that was a very generous move.
Photography is not allowed in the exhibition space inside. However, the exhibition space inside is full of wonderful works, so I'm glad I went.

Well maintained, planned science Center. Planetarium is superb. Entry fees are reasonably priced. Parking at 700yen for full day.

My kids (3 and 5) had a blast. Imax theater /planetarium, science demonstrations, physical activities, craft room... non stop fun for hours. It gets pretty crowded, but there is enough for everyone to do that there weren't long waits for anything. Easy to get to and prices are very reasonable. My only disappointment was the cafeteria.
I recommend  45 min movie show with Pokémon. Big space for age 5 under and clean.
The 3rd floor is awesome, 4th floor had some cool stuff, but the whole exhibit can be covered in about an hour.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-2-1 Shinkō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0001, Japan
data.name: Japan Coast Guard Museum Yokohama

reviews.text: This was a really great find! I didn’t even know the museum was there or that this incident even happened. This is a museum that has a sunken Korean spy ship on display for all to see. It’s very cool to see the bullet holes and be able to walk around the outside of the ship. They also have artifacts from the time period on display, so it’s like a nostalgic time capsule. It’s totally free to enter and they have an audio broadcast in English so check it out if you’re in the area. It’s near the Red Brick Warehouse.

Wow, what a catch! Japan Coast Guard Museum Yokohama is a must-visit, and the best part? It's absolutely free!

I was blown away by the stunning exhibits - it's like a treasure trove of maritime wonders! From cool coast guard vessels to interactive displays, there's something for everyone. Plus, the multilingual info (Japanese, English, Chinese, Korean) makes it easy peasy to understand, even for a landlubber like me!

And, wow, the actual North Korean Spy Vessel on display is a real showstopper! You can even peek inside - talk about a rare glimpse into a secretive world!

Don't be a shore-loser, head to Japan Coast Guard Museum Yokohama and discover the awesomeness of Japan's coast guard! Trust me, you won't be seasick, but seas-tastic!

Interesting display for adults and older children, focusing on a foreign spy ship retrieved from the Ocean floor. The story of the ship is explained with many artifacts recovered from it. We were given a heartfelt personal tour by the staff which really gave an insight into the ship, it's staff and the coast guard activities. The back of the ship opens to reveal an inner ship with high powered engines, inflatable boat and underwater scooter. It really is like something that might have inspired scenes in a James Bond movie.
You can see a North Korean spy boat that entered into Japanese waters and was blown up by her crew (and then recovered by the Japanese). It is free to visit

Excellent, well worth the search to find and visit, just past the Red Brick Warehouse area in Minato Mirai Yokohama area.  Amazing story of the ship itself, no denying the bullet holes, weapons, size of engines, thin hull for speed, etc.  And I noticed, those North Koreans spend the money for those powerful, durable Volvo engines, on the hidden speed boat within the main spy vessel.

data.formatted_address: 11 Nihonōdōri, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0021, Japan
data.name: News Park (Japan Newspaper Museum)

reviews.text: All in Japanese, but takes you through the history of Newspapers in Japan
Historical

The newspaper printing machine at the entrance has an impact. When I looked at such a huge and complicated machine, I could feel the ``hands'' of the people who made it. It's amazing.
The exhibition featured a special feature on newspaper reports about the coronavirus. You can see the sincere efforts of each newspaper company in chronological order.
The article that left the most impression on me in the exhibition was an article written by a continental war correspondent during the war that said, ``Soldiers need to be careful about infectious diseases.'' It seems that the infectious disease has claimed many victims. It is also said that Shiki Masaoka, Shimei Futabatei, and Takuboku Ishikawa died from infectious diseases, and I think that newspapers that are aware of these facts are trying to fulfill their responsibility as news media.
I wasn't able to read all the articles, so I would like to visit again.

I try to go to the Japan Newspaper Museum once a year in January if possible. (Actually, I don't get to go very often.) The reason is that around this time of year, there is an exhibition of press photos taken of the previous year's news. The Press Photo Exhibition not only displays decisive moments captured by newspaper photographers and reporters, but also displays the best shots taken by newspaper companies. Anyway, are you going to take this many historical moments? You can see some amazing moments. I remember being so surprised when I first started using it. There was a lot of sports happening last year, including the soccer World Cup, the Winter Olympics, the assassination of former Prime Minister Abe, and the war in Ukraine, but looking back on the videos makes an impact.
I took a look at the permanent exhibition for the first time in several years. The exhibits had a lot of content and were quite worth seeing.

It was fun! I thoroughly enjoyed the temporary exhibitions and permanent exhibitions.
The exhibits on the history of mass media, reporting, and page creation are worth seeing, and there are also exhibits of actual newspapers, including local newspapers from all over the country, making this a must-see for newspaper lovers!
It seems like you can search for workshops and past articles, so it seems like you can learn a lot by visiting with your kids (the permanent exhibition is more for kids).

reviews.text:
I wish I read the reviews before visiting!
The museum/gallery has been closed for many years and now it’s finally reopened, but what a disappointment.

The entrance fee is high at 2,500 per person but the ‘exhibits’ were generally weak and of poor quality. I’ve seen better art work from first year undergraduates than what was on public display here.
My friend and I wanted to leave almost immediately, but felt after the expensive entrance fee we will walk around the whole place. In total we were there for 20 minutes, and really disappointed.

For anyone who wants to look at traditional art: Don't visit a contemporary art museum. You're bound to be disappointed.

I visited the museum during the Yokohama Trienale 2024 and it was INCREDIBLE. The exhibition was extremely well curated, put together and included the work of many wonderful artists from all over the world. I couldn't have wished for anything more. I will never forget this day well spent and will definitely return on my next trip to Japan!
I see that some reviews are critical of what was displayed while I think it was exactly the choice in displays that i loved so much. It was socially aware, brought up contemporary issues such as police brutality and did it in such a smart way.. as an example,  videos of police brutality were present in almost every room, making you less and less likely to watch it as you walked through the exhibition - as an analogy to the real world where people look away because they've "seen it so many times before".
I attended the Yokohama  Triennale. It was spectacular. Amazing museum.

beautiful curation of pieces from all over the world, both political and interpretive

I think it is a hidden tourist spot in Yokohama.
If you come to Yokohama Station, please come and visit us.

Despite it being a sunny day during the 5th Golden Week, there weren't many people around, so you could enjoy the scenery around the station, including the buildings and the ocean. It gives you a sense of calm in the crowded Yokohama.

And above all, it's amazing that despite being such a wonderful place, it's open to the public for free!

Since it is located on the 12th floor, it is common to use the elevator, but we also recommend riding the escalator and enjoying the various shops and stylish interiors!

data.formatted_address: 1 Chome-1 Shinko, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0001, Japan
data.name: Akarenga Park

reviews.text: A really great park next to the red brick buildings. You can get some great views in either direction.

Akarenga Park offers a picturesque bayside promenade alongside restored warehouses and vibrant flower displays. Renowned for its stunning night views and captivating light shows, this urban haven is an ideal spot for those interested in cultural pastimes and serene relaxation.

Historical Significance
- Iconic Red Brick Warehouse.
- Blends historical charm with modern recreation.
Scenic Beauty
- Waterfront promenade with views of Yokohama Bay.
- Allure of the Yokohama Landmark Tower.
Leisure Activities
- Shopping and dining within warehouses.
- Seasonal festivals and cultural events.
- Picnic-friendly green spaces.
Accessibility
- Proximity to Yokohama Station and Sea Bass access.
- Cruise options available from the waterfront.
Nighttime Experience
- Spectacular night views.
- Light and water shows, including drone technology.
Family and Social Atmosphere
- Favorable for family outings.
- Food stalls and a variety of refreshments.

Next to the Red Brick Warehouse, it is the open area for sit, walk and enjoy any weather. Good for having a break, sit and talk, or eat. There are green grass patches and benches to sit. A couple of cruise options to Yokohama Station are also available from this waterfront. Also a good place to enjoy and participate in the events happening in the premises.

Akarenga Park in Yokohama is a delightful urban oasis that seamlessly blends historical charm with modern leisure. As a visitor with an affinity for both culture and relaxation, I found this park to be a true gem in the heart of the city.

The park's centerpiece is the iconic Red Brick Warehouse, a remnant of Yokohama's rich maritime history. The historic architecture, coupled with the serene waterfront setting, creates a captivating ambiance that transports visitors back in time. The warehouse has been repurposed into a vibrant shopping and dining complex, adding a contemporary touch to the historical site.

Strolling along the park's promenade, I was treated to stunning views of Yokohama Bay and the Yokohama Landmark Tower, adding to the picturesque allure of the location.

Akarenga Park is a popular gathering spot for locals and tourists alike, offering a wide array of events and seasonal festivals throughout the year. The lively atmosphere, coupled with the lush greenery, provides a perfect setting for picnics and social gatherings.

As a culture enthusiast, I appreciated the occasional art exhibitions and performances that added an artistic flair to the park's offerings.

In conclusion, Akarenga Park in Yokohama is a must-visit destination for anyone seeking a blend of history, leisure, and natural beauty. The harmonious integration of the Red Brick Warehouse's historical significance with the modern amenities and scenic waterfront creates an enchanting and dynamic experience. Whether you're exploring Yokohama or simply seeking a serene escape, Akarenga Park promises an unforgettable journey through the city's cultural and natural splendor.
My favorite place..you can walk from landmark tower or you can take  Sea Bass provides access from East Gate of Yokohama Station (Yokohama Bay Quarter) to Minato Mirai to Red-Brick Warehouse.
