data.formatted_address: 1562-1 Kamigōchō, Sakae Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 247-0013, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Nature Observation Forest

reviews.text: Great hiking course for family
Large park, numerous toilet buildings.  Great place for hiking.  Park center building has activities for children, books.  Parking is paid.

I found this place by chance while driving.

You can walk through the mountains, and each route has a name.

I chose the ``Dandelion Path'' because I thought it would be easy, but it was quite a distance and some parts of the path were muddy from the rain the day before.

The photo was taken at a place along the way, and it was a puddle that looked like a small pond.

We finished the walk quickly due to the humid heat and mosquito attacks.

On the second floor of ``Mori no Ie'' there is a restaurant ``kokko'' where you can eat, and we had delicious pizza baked in a wood oven.

The restaurant's recommendation was a curry set with plenty of vegetables, but I didn't choose it because my appetite was in pizza mode.

When I saw other people ordering curry sets and seeing them come out, I felt a little regretful that I should have ordered them there.

The set also comes with a salad, but it was more filling than I expected.

If I go there next time, I would like to get the curry set.

If you bring your receipt to the front desk on the 1st floor, you will receive a parking discount.

This is a visit from Daimaruyama, the highest mountain in Yokohama City.
As the name suggests, it's spacious and full of nature.
The hiking course is well maintained, but there were some parts that were not passable. I think it's perfect for bird watching and hiking.

I visited at the beginning of October. I went to inspect the campground, but unlike private campgrounds, it was quite small and there were no tent sites, so you had to use the tents that had already been set up. There are no shops, and the gates are closed at night, making it difficult to buy anything, and there are no shops nearby, so it seems difficult to camp normally. This is a facility where children can participate in outdoor classes in nature observation education, and where citizens can interact with nature. It's a great place to be as an oasis where you can relax even a little bit in the middle of a large residential area. There were people jogging and people spreading out their lunch boxes. There are many vending machines for drinking water, but the restaurants are closed, and even if they are open, they are only open for guests and on weekends, so it is better to bring your own food. Also, please note that there is no information pamphlet for the facility in the main building, so you will have to walk to the nature observation center.

data.formatted_address: 5-chōme-15-1 Kamariyahigashi, Kanazawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 236-0042, Japan
data.name: Kanazawa Zoological Gardens

reviews.text: Still one of our fave places to visit that’s very nearly in our backyard. It’s quite close, inexpensive and my kids still love the zoo! The ajisai were in full bloom making the walk around the park even more enjoyable! Still enjoy the entrance into the zoo as it’s the most unique thing I’ve ever seen. Some of animatronic need to be fixed as they aren’t as animated as the used to be.

Nice place.
Quite a few hills to climb, and it's already near the top of a big hill, great views between animals.
Animals seem happy enough, if a little lonely. Easy to get a good view of most of them.
Plenty of toilets, well spaced and placed around.
Good spaces for stopping for a picnic, bring your own or buy on site.
Sculptures and art works are also shared, some are fun others very life like.
Beware the bus back down to the railway station doesn't run for an hour around midday 😯😳

Awesome spot to spend a whole day with kids and family. Opens at 9:30 am and closes at 4:30 pm but the parking closes at 5:00.
Ample parking space @ 600 yen for one time but need to pay while entering . One parking is close to the zoo main entrance and other little far away but they have shuttle bus run in every 10 minutes intervals. As the zoo section is located on the top of the hill bus ride is better idea. Zoo entrance fee is 500yen/adult and 200 yen/child the age of 4 and above. On Saturdays entrance fee free for less than Jr High students.
This zoo has the biggest elephant in japan  also with ivory. And the first Okapi ( cross breed of giraffe and zebra ) was brought in this zoo in whole Japan.
Kangaroo and koala zone is in separate area. Many grey kangaroo on one place. Fortunately we could see kangaroo fight.

The best attraction for kids is the playing park with long and stiff slide. It's better is to take Flexible Flyer snow seat sled , as it was a burning feeling while riding on the slide with kids.
Many animals preserved.
There are good toilet facility.
Other additional facilities for having lunch with hot water provision , most of the water taps has hand soap placed.

This is a beautiful place to take in.... you enter to a wonderful place to take a picture complete with the date. The stroll to the different animals is lined with beautiful trees and flowers. 🎋🎍🌸🌷Most of the animals were quite active while we were there 🦒🐏🐐🐘🦏🦛🐨🐓🦘and my granddaughter especially loved the monkey! 🐒 A petting area also for the kids as well as an area to have a picnic and for the kids to play! Also plenty of restrooms throughout.

Our family of 3 generations enjoyed a day trip to Yokohama zoo. It is a spacious place with lovely animals. My son loves the kangaroos, elephants with the hugest tusks and of course, the koalas. We walked together for 6 hours and had a lot of fun!

data.formatted_address: 14-1 Yamashitachō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Marine Tower

reviews.text:
I feel this place is underrated!!! I visited this tower due to the All Japan Tower stamp rally and really enjoyed it.

A good amount of things to see/do at the base. At night, they are not open.

Staff is friendly. The views are nice.

This is a great way to see Yokohama skyline and harbor. You can go during the day or night but I went at twilight and saw a great skyline. It was pretty windy and you could feel the tower moving a little bit it’s near the water so a short walk to visit you won’t be disappointed

Wonderful panoramic views of Yokohama. Daytime tickets ¥1000 switch to night time tickets of ¥1200 at 6pm. We chilled on floor 2 near the shop until 6pm, then were shown to the lift by attentive staff. The whole experience was lovely. Yokohama looks beautiful from the ground but even better from the top of Marine Tower!

Not exactly for those with fear of heights. I was shook when I realized that the elevator had windows that look out the tower as you go up, and the viewing deck was quite tiny compared to those of the Tokyo Skytree. Nonetheless, I highly enjoyed the views and had quite some fun up there. Too bad it was too cloudy to see Mount Fuji but the surrounding views were still worth a visit.

We also got tickets from Klook partnered with Gundam tickets. Try considering that on your next trip.

Photos and Videos taken: March 20, 2024 (Wednesday)

Tickets were bundled with Gundam Yokohama via Klook. The tower was quite old but clean and well-maintained. Not many tourists go here. There were no lines and you can finish the tour in 30 minutes or less. It was a little rainy that day.

data.formatted_address: 6-chōme-2-9 Minatomirai, Nishi Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 220-0012, Japan
data.name: Yokohama Anpanman Children's Museum

reviews.text: It was nice to be able to buy various goods related to Japanese animation, which I loved the most as a child. However, if you are a traveler without children, I do not recommend purchasing an inside ticket. The interior is decorated only for children and you have to wait at least 30 minutes to buy and eat bread.

Shame on this place for sullying the good name of Anpanman. We paid 2800 per person (including for our 1 year old) for absolutely nothing. Do not support this horrible ripoff. Seriously, there is one floor with a few interactive exhibits. Imagine one long hallway with a few little things to do. That's it. It might be fun except the place is horrendously overcrowded, bordering on dangerous for young children. If it cost 500 yen, I wouldn't be complaining, but no... I cannot fathom the mass hypnosis that leads people to think that taking your children here is a more worthwhile time than going to a park for free. Everyone is insane. Why why why?
Expect insane crowds, long lines and waits, and an overwhelmingly disappointing selection of things to do. Go out into the city, go to a park, spend your money on Tokyo Disney (it's not that much more if you think about it!). Anything but this garbage.
Just think about the profit that this place must take in infuriates me.

A great place for kids to play and run around, as well as watch some performances by a real-life Anpanman and his friends.
If your child loves Anpanman, I'd really recommend going. This is a great place for kids to play and interact with all sorts of Anpanman related sets.

You do need to reserve a ticket (I don't think you can even buy them at the door, at least not as far as I've seen). Buggy's are not allowed inside, but there's a massive parking area for them.

There's also a few souvenir shops and a massive restaurant downstairs. These are also accesible without visiting the museum (at least the souvenir shops are).

Also keep in mind, the shows and everything there is in Japanese. It is also 'just' a playground. There's nothing museum-y about it. No history, no pictures or displays one would expect in a museum.
And as a foreigner, I personally felt a bit out of place. But our son absolutely loved it, so I loved it too.

All in all, this was a great trip for the little one, and hopefully we can go back on the future when.he's jist a little bit older.

Anpanman Children’s Museum in Yokohama: A Wholesome Adventure for Families

If you find yourself in Yokohama, Japan, with little ones in tow, a visit to the Anpanman Children’s Museum is an absolute must. Inspired by the beloved Japanese anime series “それいけ！アンパンマン” (Let’s Go! Anpanman), this museum immerses visitors in the whimsical world of Anpanman and his delightful friends.

[What to Expect]
Jam Ojisan’s Bakery: Step into Jam Ojisan’s cozy bakery, where the delightful aroma of freshly baked bread fills the air. While you won’t find individual bread items for sale on weekends, fear not! They offer set packages of 2, 4, or 8 pieces. The bread selection remains consistent, ensuring a delightful experience for all.
Exclusive Mini-Books: For the little bookworms, there’s a treat in store. The museum offers mini-books that you won’t find anywhere else. These tiny treasures are like a slice of heaven for kids, transporting them deeper into the Anpanman universe.

[Practical Information]
1. Location
The museum is conveniently situated in Yokohama’s Minato Mirai district.

2. Admission
The museum has both paid and free floors. Explore the free first floor, where you can take memorable photos and enjoy interactive exhibits. For a deeper dive into Anpanman’s world, head to the paid museum section.

3. Showtime
Don’t miss the lively stage shows featuring Anpanman and friends. Sing along, dance, and create lasting memories.

4. Souvenirs
The museum shop offers exclusive Anpanman merchandise. From socks to jigsaw puzzles, you’ll find delightful keepsakes to take home.

Whether your little ones dream of meeting Anpanman, dancing with Melonpanna, or exploring Currypanman’s culinary creations, the Anpanman Children’s Museum promises a day of joy, laughter, and imagination. 🍞🎨🌟

We all had a fantastic time! There's spots for strollers at different locations, since they're not allowed inside. So you can bring one, if you're comfortable leaving it somewhere. Wear comfortable shoes you'll be running after the kiddos and squatting or kneeling during the shows. Very important! Reserve your ticket online before you go!! We bought tickets there, online. And had to wait a few hours because the tickets are in time slots. You cannot just show up and buy tickets somewhere at a counter.
The bread in the bakery is sooo good..

reviews.text: This was a super fun roller coaster! No inversions, but the helixes and hills were plenty fun! The ride felt long, and was very enjoyable.

This was my first time ever on a rollercoaster. I was put in the first wagon after waiting a bit. The price is acceptable, the ride only takes 2 minutes, but it felt like 2 hours. And when I got off I confusedly uttered "Tsugoy" to the assistant that was very amused at my experience and smile :).
We love riding in here and also my 9yrs old son 😍

reviews.text: Very nice Japanese garden. Not crowded, quiet, overall great and relaxing experience. On a clear day you can even see Mount Fuji from one of the pagodas. Strongly recommend if you are in Yokohama.

Beautiful gardens. I thought 900 yen was a bit steep but it took quite a long time to go everywhere and gardens were well maintained. The highlight was the tea shop. The dango were great,  I got the sesame and the special with different spring toppings.

Worth the money as the place is clean and the views are amazing. Saw japanese taking their wedding pictures which was nice.
900 yen per person for entry(parking charges are separate). The garden is beautiful and well maintained. You can enjoy it for a picnic.

Really beautiful garden with lots of historically significant architecture.  Lots of places to take amazing photos that this place is often used for Japanese wedding photos.  During Sakura season is especially beautiful.  Some areas look like a scene from “Last Samurai”.

A nice and large garden. I would recommend accessing via the northern entrance as it’s more accessible. The garden is clean and well-tended. A flock of ducks can be seen swimming in the large pond. The old residence can be accessed however no tea ceremony is performed.

Downhill? I also like that there are restrictions.

500 yen. It feels cheap.

A perfect attraction for kids!

reviews.text:
Lovely park even on a lightly raining spring day. On one side is a beautiful garden with lots of flowers. Though there were also different kinds of roses, I honestly didn’t realise that there were so many different kinds.

And on the other side were floral exhibits. I don’t know what the occasion was for, but it was good to catch it.

Hopefully I can see it again when the sun is out!

A nice place to stop by and relax at the benches. preferably come before it gets dark if you want to see the flowers.
Saw some few statues (that prob meant something important)

Love this park! Probably one of the best i been too, went on a lovely stroll with my family and it was really nice, Although it was quite crowded due to it being quite a popular place. But apart of that i totally recommend going here for a walk!

The park's sea deck is an absolute highlight. The view of the ocean is breathtaking, and it provides the perfect backdrop for a relaxing day out. We spent hours just soaking in the scenery and enjoying the gentle sea breeze.

But what really stole the show was seeing my daughter play all day long. The park is incredibly family-friendly, with plenty of open spaces, playgrounds, and areas for kids to run around and explore. It was heartwarming to see her having such a blast, and it made our visit to Yamashita Park truly memorable.

Overall, if you're in Yokohama and looking for a peaceful escape by the sea, Yamashita Park is the place to be. Whether you're with family, friends, or just looking to unwind solo, this park has something for everyone. Highly recommended! 🌊👧🏻🌳

A great place to stroll around and spend time. There's a free bicycle park available. You can enjoy the waves, ship views, sunset, and dogs playing. There's also a ship museum nearby that you can visit. Additionally, it's close to the Gundam Factory, so even if you don't want to go inside and pay for a ticket, you can still watch the Gundam from outside.

data.formatted_address: 20-5 Hisakichō, Isogo Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 235-0015, Japan
data.name: Hama Market

reviews.text: Traditional style shopping arcade with old shops and reasonable prices.

This is a very busy shopping street that can be reached in 5 to 6 minutes by bus bound for Isogo Station from Negishi Station's No. 5 bus stop.

It's a locally-based arcade town, and I was overwhelmed with emotion to finally arrive here, but it was closed during the year-end and New Year holidays, and all stores were closed on that day.

As an arcade fanatic, I'm surprised that there are so many cool arcades left in the Kanto region.

Next time I want to come on a business day.

A Showa-style shopping street that was created as a result of the post-war black market. The arcade was built in 1954 (Showa 29), and the atmosphere of that time remains.
There are greengrocers, fishmongers, butchers, delicatessen shops, flower shops, etc., as well as several cafes and restaurants serving Korean food.
The communal restroom is, of course, Japanese style.
Free bicycle parking available. There are also several affiliated coin parking lots.
There seems to be a flea market held regularly.
A nostalgic shopping street from the Showa era. We were all like this when we were kids. Fried food from a butcher shop is delicious, isn't it?

A shopping street with a Showa feel
Vegetables, meat and fish were extremely cheap, and the triangular croquettes were exquisite.
There is an affiliated parking lot nearby, but it's not worth it since one store offers 30 minutes free for purchases over 2,200 yen.

data.formatted_address: 1-1 Yamanouchichō, Kanagawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 221-0054, Japan

reviews.text:
I don’t know how I ended up finding this as a tour, but it was a very awesome experience. We got to see the purchasers buy the regular seafood, followed by blue fin tuna inspection, and ultimately the bidding action on the bluefins. We then followed visited the freezer vault where the tuna are held! We saw a master anago butcher work his craft. Everyone in the building was so nice and kept giving us souvenirs. Our guide Masa and interpreter Nagomi provided an excellent experience.

The only downside was how far this was from where we were staying in Tokyo! But this is my own fault and not the tours at all. I should have looked at the map better before booking! But if you have the time or the will to do this, it’s a truly unique and interesting experience.

I went to the all-you-can-stuff frozen fish on March 2nd. It seems that the first and third Saturday of the month is public open day, and events are held in various places. It started at 8 a.m., and customers were lining up from the moment they opened for the all-you-can-stuff frozen fish items. The all-you-can-fill ice cream and tuna dissection show looked fun. There is a large and free parking lot. There are well-maintained toilets. There is also a restaurant where you can eat fresh fish, so I think you will enjoy it no matter how many times you go. Don't forget to bring a cooler bag 🙌

The tuna in the sashimi set meal at Kosei Shokudo, located on the premises of the market, is bluefin tuna. For 800 yen, you can't get that sashimi set meal anywhere else. This is not a store for the general public, so please be aware of this before coming to the store.
You should go when the market is open twice a month. You can buy delicious fish at low prices.

According to the website, the end of the year opens at 8am, and when I arrived just before 8am, the parking lot was already 80% full. When I headed to the market, many people had already finished shopping and were returning home. When I entered the market, I saw many shops that were already out of stock and closed. What time is the correct time to come? Some of the prices are cheaper than those at the supermarket, and some are not, so I understand that it is necessary to understand the market price well in advance. Well, the good thing about it is that it's fresh. Processed products seem to be cheaper than fresh fish.

data.formatted_address: 148 Yamashitachō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan
data.name: Chinatown Market Street

reviews.text: Small narrow street with hanging lanterns within Chinatown called Market Street with restaurants, street foods, and souvenir vendors.
Small street with a lot of lanterns.

The name "Ichiba Street" originates from around 1921, before the Great Kanto Earthquake, when Chinese restaurants and their residents spontaneously opened a store for butchers, fresh fish stores, fruit and vegetable stores, tofu specialty stores, bean sprout specialty stores, egg specialty stores, and dried food stores. At that time, stores started opening on the street, which was called the morning market and was open only in the morning. Due to shortages of supplies after the end of the Pacific War, this market street was called Morning Market Street and was very busy, but from around 1960 to 1965, as eating habits changed, general stores gradually withdrew and Chinese restaurants moved in. I am very happy.
There are various gates in this Chinatown, so I want to complete them.

Gate on the north side of Market Street.

Although Market Street is not a very large street, it is crowded with people on holidays.

reviews.text: If you need to buy groceries near Yokohama, then BRANCH is the place for you. There are different grocery stores available, such as Ave, as well as a public market with fresh vegetables/seafood! We came later in the day, so I would recommend coming here in the morning when all the shops still have an abundance of food. There are also a handful of different restaurants here if you get hungry while grocery shopping. There is a rooftop deck for you to relax while your kids play. There are also a few dollar-type stores here, too. Overall, it was fun to explore, but I probably won't be back because I don't live close by/not worth the 40-minute drive.
If Costco is not the option for you then this Nambu Market is the best choice. 2 big supermarkets and couple of open markets. We brought crab here and price was reasonable and quality was good.

Yokohama Nanbu Market is an excellent place to experience the vibrant food culture of Japan. The outdoor market is located in the heart of the city and offers an extensive selection of fresh fruits and vegetables. Even though I visited on a rainy day and had to park my bike outside, I was impressed by the energy and variety of the market. The produce was exceptionally fresh and well-priced, and the market was bustling with vendors and shoppers alike.

One of my favorite things about Yokohama Nanbu Market was the availability of local specialties like strawberries and avocados. The strawberries were plump, sweet, and juicy, while the avocados were perfectly ripe and creamy. I also appreciated the range of other produce on offer, including leafy greens, root vegetables, and fresh herbs.

Aside from the fresh produce, there were also vendors selling handmade crafts and traditional Japanese snacks. The atmosphere was lively and welcoming, and I enjoyed chatting with vendors and other shoppers.

Overall, I highly recommend visiting Yokohama Nanbu Market for anyone interested in discovering the flavors and culture of Japan. Despite the outdoor parking and rainy weather, the market was an unforgettable experience, and I left with a basket full of fresh produce and happy memories.
Cheap prices for grocery shopping at Ave.  There are some restaurants and a few concession stands to eat at.  Nojima and a Docomo shop are also there.

What a great place for shopping!  Bunches of stores with some incredible pricing.  You'll want to get there early.  Seems the parking is free for now but there are parking gates installed so it can be changed at any time.   Also, the parking lot isn't the easiest to drive around. Some of the events that happen there are a lot of fun.  For example, the Brazilian dancing.  Most stores open at 10 but some as early as 9, check the webpage for details.   Loved the fruit & vegetable store as well as the supermarket.

data.formatted_address: 140 Yamashitachō, Naka Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 231-0023, Japan

reviews.text:
First of all, it's not a Shinto Shrine nor a Buddhist temple. It's a Taoist temple dedicated to a few Chinese gods.

It's a small temple with wonderful intricate carvings and designs. And like most temples which should not be for profit, it's free to visit and enter.

It's a must-stop if you're visiting Yokohama Chinatown.

We only visited this temple from the outside (you need to pay a ticket to enter). It is very small and, even just from the outside, it already shows its great beauty. There are numerous details of the Thaoist culture, as well as beautiful gold decorations almost everywhere. It was nice to be able to contemplate the sound of its silence and the smell of its incense, in a special atmosphere.

This temple in Yokohama Chinatown houses the widely revered warrior Guan Yu. This famous general from the History of the Three Kingdoms was later deified and is the primary figure of worship at this temple.
A beautiful Buddhist shrine in Yokohama Chinatown. Admission is free and you’re not obligated to buy anything.

A beautiful temple to visit, right in Chinatown.  Wonderful designs and architecture with eye catching colors throughout.  The inside temple has five areas to pray and give offerings.  The assistants are nice and very helpful in passing along their knowledge of the temple.  A must see!

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒231-0811 Kanagawa, Yokohama, Naka Ward, Honmokufutō, １−１６
data.name: Yokohama Port Symbol Tower

reviews.text:
Constructed in July 1986, the tower stands at a height of 58.5 meters (191.92 ft) and is situated on Jetty D of Honmoku Pier. It serves as a ship traffic signal station, ensuring the safe navigation of passenger and cargo vessels from around the world as they enter and exit the Port of Yokohama.

The tower features an observation deck near its summit, providing panoramic views of the port. Visitors should take note that this tower serves a more utilitarian purpose than being a typical tourist attraction, as it lacks an elevator. To reach the observation deck, you need to ascend 16 short flights of stairs, totaling 140 steps up to the 4th floor.

Curated links for further reading can be found at the Pix4Japan blog post dated Sept. 6th.

A not-bad-place to come if you definitely, absolutely and truly have nothing else to do.
Don’t expect too much of the observation deck as the window glasses are as dirty as the walls.
And if you think there will be elevator to bring you to the top floor, you are wrong.
Fantastic, unique park within the port and dockyards. Bring binoculars to ship-watch. Rin Rin loves the view and places to run around.

Short time visit I suppose to say. Short walk, nice view of ocean is nice. Sitting some tree is a relaxing for reading too. Only one bus were available per hour so if you could bring your car is best.
If you are tired of crowded Minatomirai area in Yokohama, must visit here. Its all free, even the observation deck access.

June 2, 2024, afternoon visit

A gallery located south of Yokohama Chinatown, near Suzakumon.
There was a solo exhibition by Keiko Hanma, an illustrator from Kohama Island, so I went to visit her.
An open design with a glass-enclosed gallery that allows you to see clearly from the street.

The hydrangeas at the entrance of the building where the gallery is located are starting to change color and look beautiful.

I went there because there was an exhibition of original pictures from a picture book written by a friend. It's located on the edge of Motomachi Chinatown, about 3 minutes from the Minato Mirai Line station, and when it's open, you can see what's going on inside from the lights from the street, so you can easily find it.
It's a small art space, but the person in charge was friendly and gave me detailed information about the drawing teacher.
I watched Yoko Matsuda's solo exhibition "episode".

Gallery in Yamashita-cho, Yokohama
The front is glass, so it's not big, but it's a bright and open space (^^)
It's close to the subway station and near Chinatown, but I was able to enjoy the show in peace without the hustle and bustle.

Although it is a gallery near Suzaku Gate in Chinatown, it is not noisy and you can stop by and touch the art while sightseeing.
We carry a wide variety of artists, so I think you'll be able to find one you like as you visit.

reviews.text:
This visit will be on April 29, 2024. Advance reservations are required (admission fee is 400 yen for individuals/300 yen for groups). Inside, in addition to forests and gardens, there is an old private house owned by a local celebrity, Mr. Tanabe, and an art museum.

The promenade is full of greenery, and although it is difficult to maintain it, we are still passionate about protecting what is important to us. In the forest, there are also works by Mitsuaki Tanabe, a sculptor and the father of the current owner.

Yasutaka Tanabe: 12th generation head of the family. The old folk house in the park serves as a memorial to this person. As a celebrity, he has many achievements.
Mr. Mitsuaki Tanabe: 13th generation head of the family. WILD stainless steel sculptor. When he was young, his face resembles the teacher from School〇OO's.
Ryomitsu Tanabe: 14th generation = current head of the family. A person who gives explanations at an old folk house. His loving and popular conversations are skillful and appealing.

There is also a pond in the garden, with many fine carp swimming around. Also on display is Mitsuaki's work ``WILD Banana Seeds''. I hope this beautiful place will remain forever.

There is also an art museum next to the entrance, where you can see many works by Mitsuaki, who was connected to multiple countries and left behind many works.

This is an art museum with a lush garden.
It is located along the slope of the hill that continues from Idayama on the Kawasaki City side.
This hilly area is an old land, and there are many sites such as Shimoguchi shell middens, Kanba burial mounds, and remains of pit dwellings.
There is also a lot of spring water, and it is also a place where wild plants such as wild orchids remain.

The road near the museum entrance is sandwiched between a bamboo forest and the greenery of the garden museum, making it cool even in summer.

It is an art museum with a multifaceted character, including an old folk house, a garden, and a sculpture museum.

Unlike art museums run by public or large corporations, I think this is a unique art museum with deep roots in the local community.
It was a lovely garden. Is it the owner? She was a wonderful woman and we talked about a lot of things.

Along with the museum, there are gardens and old folk houses.
We were asked to kindly and carefully learn about the 400-year history of the Tanabe family.
I lived nearby 50 years ago, so it made me feel very nostalgic.
thank you very much.

reviews.text: Very nice small museum with some wonderful pieces on display.  Also, remember to look up, a few light fixtures are part of the exhibition :)

This visit will be on February 17, 2024. This is an art museum located near Shin-Takashima Station. It was apparently established by Mr. Tsurumi (deceased), the founder of the Teruhiko Tsurumi Scholarship Foundation, a public interest incorporated foundation, with his personal assets, and it is located on the second floor of the Yokohama Dental College, which was also founded by him.

Apparently, Mr. Tsurumi was a collector of glass crafts, so there are many shining glass crafts displayed on the dark floor. There is only one room inside the museum, but it is quite spacious. He seems to be well-versed in stained glass, so there are a lot of art pieces that make you think, ``I see.''

The admission fee is 800 yen, but there are various discounts available, so be sure to check beforehand (particularly free for junior high school students and younger and those with a disability certificate).

Since it is an art museum, there are various restrictions, but it is OK to take photos inside the museum. Also, please note that there is no parking lot.

Although it is a small museum, it is packed with exhibits, not only showcases but also lights from the ceiling.
You can take pictures freely, so it takes a while to take a good look at it, so it's very satisfying.
You can see Galle's delicate and beautiful glass vessels. The exhibition room is not very large, but I think the works belonging to the museum are treated with great care.

Since I didn't have much time, I decided to go to a small museum, so I did a Google search and found this museum.
It is a museum with only one floor.
This time it was the exhibition ``Art Nouveau & Art Deco: A Feast of Glass and Light''.
I went there wondering if it was empty, but there were about 5 groups in quick succession, starting with me, and it was a bit chaotic.
I thought that even though the museums in the city are small, people still gather there.
The receptionist was polite and took care of my luggage, and I was allowed to take photos (no flash allowed).
The entrance is at the back, but there is an easy-to-understand signboard, and the venue is on the second floor, but you can take the elevator up.
It was a nice museum that you can see in about an hour (maybe even longer if you like it).
A short walk from Shin-Takashima Station.

data.formatted_address: 112 Kamishiranechō, Asahi Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 241-0001, Japan
data.name: Furusato Onemichi Ryokudo Promenade

reviews.text: Stunning promenade ideal for walking, jogging and running. Lots of beautiful parks along the way and especially beautiful during the cherry blossom season.

It is a pedestrian-only road of approximately 1.6 km that runs from the point across the Nakahara Kaido intersection of Yokohama Kyoryo High School to Tsurugamine Junior High School.
Restrooms and benches are located at Imajuku Higashi Park along the way.
There are several stairs to climb and descend on the way, but there are no steep slopes, so I think it's a fairly easy walk.
There are trails through the forest and some nice views, so I think you'll have a lot of fun♪

It starts at the top of the long (very steep) stairs next to the convenience store at the Tsurugamine bus rotary entrance and continues all the way to the end of Zoorasia.

It is a green road that changes in each season. Cherry blossom season, fresh greenery, hydrangeas, autumn leaves, etc.

Many people walk and run from morning until evening. Sometimes there are dog gatherings 🐕

However, despite the signboard, there are many people passing by on bicycles and motorcycles. Sometimes there are no-good people who will retaliate or complain if you warn them.

Depending on the time of year, Higashi Park, which is in the middle of a forest, can become untouched and full of grass and insects to the point where you can't play in it, but in the summer it's about -5 degrees cooler than other parks.

When the Lake Sagami waterway passes through Zoorasia and crosses Nakahara Kaido, above and beside it becomes a promenade called ``Furusato-one-do Greenway''. In spring, the rows of cherry blossom trees in full bloom are truly spectacular. Many people come from far and wide to watch.

At a low point, a concrete structure canal can be seen. During the winter, concrete heat shrinks, opening the joints and allowing water to leak. When the temperature rises, thermal expansion closes the gaps and stops the leak. A somewhat odd structure. This supports the lives of Yokohama citizens.

A promenade along the ridge built above the waterway. There are some breaks where the water line crosses the road, but it's a comfortable walk for about 1.7km. The trees that have been planted are well taken care of, and I think it will be very crowded during the cherry blossom season.

data.name: Shasui Falls

reviews.text:
Date visited: November 2022
I am always fascinated of Waterfalls. A wonderful experience to have fresh air and nature feels away from the city. The sound of the rushing water gives a refreshing vibes. Cool place to unwind in such a relaxing surrounding.

Date of visit: Jan 4 2024.
It is a 30 min walk from the Yamazaki station. It is mostly a flat walk. You can visit the falls upto the bridge or see it from above by climbing the staircase of 226 steps.
There is a cafe right at the entrance to the falls. There was one restaurant on the way close to the station as well.
Good day trip from Tokyo.
If you are into aquariums you could consider visiting the last station of the Gotunda line as well.

Located near the head of the Tanzawa River, this waterfall is part of Saishō-ji, a Buddhist temple that is located nearby.

The waterfall is only a 5-minute walk from the parking area provided for tourists located shortly downstream.

The falls are used by the clergy and monks of the nearby Saisho-ji Temple, and is also a holy site for Japanese mountain ascetic hermits. Members of both traditions stand directly under the fall and endure the water striking the head and upper body during a purification ceremony.

Unfortunately, super typhoon, Typhoon Hagibis, wreaked havoc on this area (as well as the rest of Japan) back in October 2019.

I reached this location about an hour before sunset after a 4-hour drive. If the evening sun ever shines through the forest canopy, I was too late to witness it.

Due to the encroaching darkness, all of the shots were taken with long exposures to capture as much light as possible. I feel that the large boulders were a bit overwhelming in my composition. Maybe if there was more water volume, or maybe if I had come before the typhoon there would be less rock visible.

Although these shots are not very good and seem more cluttered than I'd like, being alone with my dog at this location was definitely worth the time and effort to get here.
Hidden beauty  of Yamakita 💯✔️👍it is the same as we  visited this place 8 years ago , except  for the newly built 226 steps to view the perfect beauty  of the falls upstairs.

Shasui Falls is a hidden gem nestled in the heart of nature, and my visit to this enchanting waterfall left me in awe of its pristine beauty.

The highlight of Shasui Falls is undoubtedly the waterfall itself. As the crystal-clear water rushes down the rugged rock formations, it creates a mesmerizing spectacle of nature's power and grace. The sight and sound of the cascading water instill a sense of serenity and wonder, making it a perfect place for relaxation and reflection.

The accessibility of Shasui Falls is another notable feature. The well-maintained trails and viewing platforms allow visitors to enjoy different angles of the waterfall, catering to both seasoned hikers and those seeking a leisurely stroll. The journey to the falls is as enjoyable as the destination, with lush greenery and natural beauty all around.

The surrounding forest adds to the allure of Shasui Falls, making it a haven for birdwatchers and wildlife enthusiasts. The park's pristine environment creates a habitat for various bird species and other wildlife, enhancing the overall experience.

In summary, Shasui Falls is a tranquil and captivating natural wonder that provides a refreshing escape from the chaos of everyday life. Whether you're a nature lover, an adventurer, or simply seeking a peaceful oasis, this waterfall is a must-visit destination that offers a profound connection to the beauty and serenity of the natural world.

Except for fishermen, fishing gear called joren and ninja rakes (rakes with wire mesh) cannot be used due to local regulations.

Please do not use these illegal fishing gears and preserve the resources.

reviews.text:
Gumyoji Temple, Yokohama City
Arrive by climbing steep stairs for 15 minutes from Gumyoji Temple.
It's not something you'd expect to visit in the summer, but there's a cool breeze when you climb up to the high ground. This is a reproduction of a pit-style dwelling from the Jomon and Yayoi periods. We also sell earthenware pendants for 500 yen in the administration building.

2023.10
[Admission fee] Free
[Opening hours] 9:00-17:00 (9:00-16:00 from October to March)
[Closed days] Mondays except holidays, year-end and New Year holidays

A small archaeological museum within the Sandondai ruins.
We preserve and display artifacts and remains excavated from the ruins, such as pottery, stone tools, and stone blades.
Experience-based events such as ``stone tool making'', ``fire making'', ``magatama making'', and ``earthenware pottery making'' seem to be held frequently.
There seems to be a camping event in the summer where you can stay overnight at the ruins.

I have visited twice. I'm sure there are volunteer guides on holidays. Ruins from the Yayoi period are preserved. The remains of a fairly large residence. 2023/4/6
I asked for a guide and it was okay. 2023/6/17

The staff are kind. I'll post the map you gave me to Gumyoji Station on the municipal subway, along with pictographs.
★The shop's pottery pendants are amazing. It follows earthenware styles such as the Miyadai style. I also liked that the magatama making kit included talc and aota stone.
★You can experience bow and arrow. Hecklers are balls and not dangerous.

national historic site

reviews.text:
This is a green patch treasure in the middle of the city. 12 min walk from the station. The moso is second to none in size and site. It's very well cared for by a keen and kind group of tender loving volunteers.
A good place for hiking and taking a break from the city to appreciate nature.

If you are on the cycling/walking path along the Tsurumi River, it’s a quick side trip to Kozukue  Castle Remains. I came across only one individual as I was approaching the entrance, and I did not see any other soul. During the pandemic, it’s wonderful not to run into anyone. While there isn’t much of the remains, the dry moat, observatory, etc., are well kept. The bamboo forest is majestic especially when the bird chirping is the only thing that breaks the silence.
hidden getaway if you want a quiet place and close to nature. not a lot of people here.
Eerie location of a 15th century castle in the middle of a bamboo-studded hill. Fantastic location, even if there is not much to see of the castle itself.

data.formatted_address: 2 Chome-25 Chigasakihigashi, Tsuzuki Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 224-0033, Japan
data.name: Chigasaki Castle Ruins Park

reviews.text: Park with some ancient ruins. Descriptions are only in Japanese

It is located a short walk from Center Minami Station. As soon as you enter the park entrance, you will find yourself on a forest road covered with trees. There are explanatory notes at key points, but even though it's a castle ruins park, it doesn't really feel like a castle ruins. Perfect for forest bathing. Just be careful of the crows. There were notice boards all over the place, and just when I thought something was wrong when someone at the top of the page started shouting, I was later threatened. The western part may be dangerous. Apparently it's a good idea to cover yourself with an umbrella. Other than that, it's very good.

I woke up in the morning and the weather wasn't great.
But should I go to the sea? ? ?
When I was looking into it, I found the ruins of a castle.
It's about an hour one way from my house, which is just the right distance.
I went and tried it.
There are also information boards explaining the castle and signs such as ↑Chubu.
It was a very nice castle ruins.
It's good that there are no documents and it's a mystery!

Although the castle ruins are unknown nationally, I am impressed by the skill and scale of their territory. Compared to Kozue Castle, the ruins have suffered very little destruction and remain in almost perfect condition. Of course, since it is a medieval earthen castle, there are no stone walls, buildings, or other attached facilities. It is also a castle full of mysteries, as there are no records of it in contemporary historical materials.
There is a theory that Yukitsuna Tada built the castle, perhaps due to local legend, but Yukitsuna was a direct descendant of the Settsu Tada-Genji clan and has little connection to the Kanto region. There's no way to prove it, but it's probably not a historical fact. However, on the way to the castle there is Jufukuji Kannondo, which is said to have been founded by Yukitsuna Tada. It is more interesting that these traditions remain than the historical facts themselves. Common sense would suggest that it was built during the Gohojo era as a supplementary castle to Kozukue Castle, and that an influential member of the Kozukue clan was appointed as the castle owner.
The guide panels set up at each of the fort ruins, earthen bridge ruins, dry moat ruins, and tiger mouth ruins are well-made and the explanations are thorough. It is also a good idea not to use words such as ``Honmaru'' and ``Ninomaru'' in reference to early modern castles.

About 10 minutes walk from Center Minami Station. If you donate 200 yen at the Yokohama Museum of History before visiting, you can receive a pamphlet, so it's a good idea to head there from Center-Kita Station.

There are two entrances to the castle ruins on the north side. The territory of the main kuos consisted of the northern kuo, the western kuo, and the eastern kuo, with the central kuo in the middle, and it seems that the daily residence (Negoya) was on the south side.

The highlights are the Koguchi between the northern and western enclosures, the Horizoko path, the ruins of a turret platform at the corner, and the large earthen mound on the south side of the middle enclosure. The eastern section is the highest and is considered the main section. The scenery here is also good.

Although it is small, it is a valuable asset left behind by urban development. It really lasted well.

data.formatted_address: 3-5 Kōgaya, Kanagawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 221-0051, Japan
data.name: Site of Gongen-yama Castle

reviews.text:
When you get off Kanagawa Station and walk along the railroad tracks, you will come to a long staircase.

When you go up these stairs, you will find an open plaza.

It's a performance.

It's a fairly small hill, and you can see many railroad tracks.

Ahead is an explanation of the remains of the Gongenyama Battle.

It seems like the era of Hojo Soun.

There are no remains of the structure, and the actual area was carved out when Kanagawa Daiba was built, and then again when the Tokaido Line was passed through, so it doesn't seem to have maintained its shape.

However, it was a good place to imagine what it would be like when the Gohojo clan expanded its influence around here.

I had some business to take the train to Yokohama, so I visited the ruins of Gongenyama Castle, which I had been interested in for some time. It takes about 5 minutes on foot from Yokohama Station.
Although it is called a castle ruin, there is only an information board on a hill with a good view (there are two levels above and below, so you can imagine a castle...), and it is now called ``Kogaya Park.''
Furthermore, on the opposite hill across the JR line (formerly connected hill) is Honkakuji Temple, where the American Consulate was located when Yokohama Port opened.

Now, regarding Gongen Yamashiro, Masamori Ueda Kurado, a vassal of the Ogigaya Uesugi family, played an active role in the Chokyo War (1487-1505, a battle between the Yamauchi and the Ogigaya Uesugi families), and took control of Kanagawa Minato, which was Yamauchi Uesugi territory. He took control and built Gongenyama Castle.

At the Battle of Tachikawara in 1504, Ogidani Uesugi Tomoyoshi [Tomoyoshi, (in the local information board) Asayoshi] won with the support of Imagawa Ujichika and Ise Sozui, but in the end In 1505, Yamauchi Uesugi Kensada, supported by Nagao Yoshikage [Yoshikage and Kenshin's grandfather], who was the shugo of the Echigo-Uesugi family, won a victory over Ogidani Uesugi Tomoyoshi, and the Chokyo Rebellion began. It ended.

Ise Sozui (later Hojo Soun), who had been plotting to advance from western Sagami to eastern Sagami, was not satisfied with this result, and in 1510, he arranged with Masamori Ueda, who was also dissatisfied with the loss of Kanagawa Minato. Masamori Ueda raised an army at Gongenyama Castle. Ise Sozui dispatched reinforcements, but was defeated by the Yamauchi and Ogidani Uesugi armies, and Gongen Yamashiro fell. 《2023.12.9 Visit》

The current Kougaya Park is said to be the site of Gongenyama Castle, the residence of Masamori Ueda, a senior vassal of the Ogigaya Uesugi clan. Masamori defected to Soun Hojo, and was attacked by the combined forces of Ogidani and Yamauchi Uesugi, leading to the Battle of Mt. Gongen. This battle is unusual in that Soun loses.
Even though it is called Mt. Gongen, it is just a small hill. The top is a wide flat area, perhaps the remains of the main castle? (Photos 2-4). There is also a flat area on the north side that looks like a sub-citadel, but I think it was built when the park was created (photos 5 to 7). I think there was also a kuruwa on the south side facing the old Tokaido, but the topography has changed and the details are unknown. Destruction of the ruins had already begun at the end of the Edo period, and when Kanagawa Daiba was being built, a large portion of Mt. Gongen was scraped away and used as land for reclamation.

It is said that it was once connected to Aoki Castle on the west side along the ridge, but it seems to have been separated by the construction of the Tokaido Line during the Meiji period. I don't really understand the relationship with Aoki Castle. The old Tokaido road runs south of the castle, so there is no doubt that it was an important transportation hub. An illustration of Kanagawa Sunago from the late Edo period depicts a long stone staircase leading from Sokoji Temple at the eastern foot of the mountain to the summit of Mt. No trace left. Although it is hard to imagine now, the southeast foothills were quite close to the coastline.
The first photo shows the hills of Mt. Gongen seen from Hongaku-ji Temple, where Aoki Castle was located.

It is said that the castle was connected along the ridge with Aoki Castle (Honkakuji Temple) across the street.
I can't say it's a clear ruin, but it's on a hill, so I guess it's the ruins of a castle.
It is said that the ridge was cut off by Route 1 and the railroad tracks, but there is an information board about the Kanagawa Honjin ruins about 400m east of the old Tokaido, and that is the old main road. hand.

Originally, Takashimadai, where Hongaku-ji Temple is located, and Mt. Gongenyama were one, and there were Aoki Castle and Gongenyama Castle. Mt. Gongen was carved out when Kanagawa Daiba (designed by Kaishu Katsu, remains of which remain near the market) was carved, and cut-outs were carved to pass the national highway and railway, so it became a separate plateau from Takashimadai. . Currently, a park is being developed on Mt. Gongen.

At Gongenyama Castle, there was a big battle during the Sengoku period (Ogigaya Uesugi vs. former vassal Ueda clan), and Hojo Soun also fought there. It is safe to say that there is no trace of what it was like back then.

reviews.text: It is a truly romantic setting, you can admire the center of the city with the cableways above you (or the city from the cabin, that is the best panorama!). Special skyline, I recommend a walk in this magical environment. Prices are ok.

One way ticket is preferred.  Both ends have a mall. Sakuragicho has a train station. The ride lasts about 5 to 6 minutes.  The staff was able to speak basic English, which made our ticket purchase easy. They also have an elevator.

At 1000 yen a pop (1800 roundtrip), you're probably not going to be rocking it Air Cabin style to the shopping mall or red brick warehouse area too often, but like so much else around here, this seems to be catering to the special event or romantic date crowd. Views are excellent and the air conditioning is solid. Views are better on the way to Sakuragicho Station. Staff was friendly and payment easy.

Most expensive mode of transportation from unga park to Sakuragicho station. 1000 yen for single and 1800 yen for return ride. You can board from unga park since there are no crowds there and waiting time is zero. Nice views though.
Perhaps only due to COVID restriction, but it was really nice that single traveler got the cabin for him/her alone! The view to the modern city is fantastic!

reviews.text: Lovely garden with a view that overlooks the town of Yokohama. Entrance is free and you can also go inside the Diplomat’s house. There is also a miniature version of the famous houses in Yamate area.
Definitely worth a visit if you are walking around Yamate District.  Beautiful views of the center of Yokohama, you can refresh yourself with cool drinks in the cafe.

Nice layout. Well-maintained garden. Free access to the house and garden area. Handicap accessible ramps. Café on site with drinks and snacks. Outdoor seating and benches are available for use. Garden has hedges and a fountain area. No parking available on-site, coin-parking sites nearby.

Lovely place with architectural design that helps you travel all the way to Europe. On a sunny day, the gardens invite visitors to walk around at peace and enjoy the beautiful of its place. Going uphill to reach the place might be a bit rough but once there you can enjoy a panoramic view of the city.
Such a lovely reprieve from the insanity of China Town. Definitely stop here after going to Moto machi.

Quiet place inside the busy city.
Having beautiful colour leaves and flowers is extreme beauty.

reviews.text: Very beautiful garden, very easily reachable by public transport from Tokio centre. Highly recommend due to the historical buildings from various Japanese eras (brought over to the garden from all over Japan), and if you would like to enjoy the Sakura Cherry Blossoming season in its full glory. Entrance is paid, but definitely worth the price.

Unfortunately, it was closed when I visited. Timing shows that it's closed during New Year (31/12-3/1). The good thing is there is no one so I can enjoy myself a lot. The view is so calm and beautiful. May be it will be amazing during autumn and Sakura.
Nothing much to see; though, it’s a nice, calm park.

This Qing Dynasty building was relocated in 1989 to commemorate the friendship between Shanghai and Yokohama. I happened to see it on my way to the south gate of Sankeien Garden, and since it was night time, it was beautifully lit up. Since it was renewed in 2021, the colors are bright and eye-catching. The hexagonal roof architecture of Koshin-tei is reflected in the lake and is a feast for the eyes.
I went last Saturday. There are many small white lotuses blooming and it is very cute.

However when I arrived at around 12:30am the parking lots are already full. You might need to plan your parking ahead to avoid wasting time looking for spot.
Motorcycle and bicyle parking space available, also is free of charge.

Beautiful park. The cherry blossoms are not ready just yet. Maybe 2 more weeks and they will be in full bloom

Edit: 28March2023 the cherry blossoms are beautiful

Amazing park, large area, ponds, temple, tennis courts, tennis wall, etc.

There are many beautiful corners, which always present a new romantic view. Some bridges, streams, the lake and water birds make you forget the everyday life for a moment.

Cherry Blossoms are stunning here. This is like a little piece of Kyoto and Shirakawago in Yokohama. I’ve visited many Folk Villages and gardens… this one is one of my favorites. There are beautiful views, great picture spots, and cool cultural spots.

Nice place for a little nature hiking in the city. There is a traditional farm house and rice is still grown here to show traditional farming methods.

Local park.  Even in elementary school, I slowly went to the place where I went on an excursion for the first time.  There were old folk houses and rice fields on the premises more than I expected, so it was fun.

Cyclers and pedestrain it's a good news that the cycle parking and entrance is free .
As I live in the 1 hour walking distance I frequently go there with my two kids and wife. Picnic spot is available. Toilet and drinking  water tap facilities available. Toilet is clean .

A day relaxing picnic with kids and playing  kits is the best .

Cheers

reviews.text: There’s aplenty of activities ongoing surrounding Zou-no-hana Park. You will see there’s a huge harbour greenland with a surface area of close to 3.3 hectares including the breakwater stretching sideways from the Osanbashi Yokohama International Port Terminal. This encompass  an event space and a resting area with a cafe gallery too. I can see dog lovers exchanging talks while their dogs interacting with one another.
Beautiful park, clear views of the Red Brick Museum as well as interesting exhibit in the middle!

Went there during the Yokohama Record Fest, the place was spacious even when full of people. The view was spectacular overlooking the pier. The weather that day made sure of an even better experience. For the food, I had an apple pi which was good, a nice apple cider with cinnamon (I think), and hot chocolate with marshmallow. Perfect to accompany our visit there.

This is a relatively new, tiny urban park (more like a rest area) on the site of a former building. It's nice that this was turned into free space rather than just another small residence or shop. There are a few benches, an informational signboard, and a reasonable view to the Minato Mirai area. This park should not be confused with large Zounohana Park across the water, which is further away from the original Zo-No-Hana breakwater than this one is. It might be easier to think of this park as Zo-No-Hana Breakwater Park.
Nice place for photo shooting!  You can enjoy the great view of Yokohama harbor.  Recommend to go around sunset!

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒236-0006 Kanagawa, Yokohama, Kanazawa Ward, Hakkeijima, 横浜・八景島シーパラダイス
data.name: Dekkai

reviews.text: My son like here eventhough we do not know where to go.We are.very happy especially my son
Fun for kids for sure, but not so much for adults
Lots of sanitizing observed at all locations

A huge three-dimensional maze. Since it was three-dimensional, I thought it was an indoor facility, but it turned out to be like a giant wooden jungle gym, exposed to the rain. What will you do in the rain?

There are 3 courses, and each course has a give-up route in the middle, so you can leave midway if you have any trouble.
According to the staff member, if you simply aim for the top, it will take 10 minutes, but if you try to collect all the stamps, it will take 30-40 minutes.
There are many walkways designed for children to crouch down, so if you're a family, you'll feel the difference in physical strength between you and your child.
However, like Hakone Zaiku, there are some doors that you can't proceed without thinking about the order in which you open them, so the beginner's course seems to be quite difficult for kindergarteners to complete.
Parents who are not confident in their physical strength should be careful not to become a hindrance to their rapidly progressing children.

I chose the shortest course, but since it was the last attraction to go to, it was tough to squat and climb up.

The child seemed to have fun and tried the next difficulty level for the second time by himself.

data.formatted_address: 4191 Nagatsutachō, Midori Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 226-0026, Japan
data.name: Field Athletics Yokohama Tsukushino course

reviews.text: Aka big adventure playground great for kids. With just 800 yen entrance fee you can enjoy 50   equipments which include water-based ones. Make sure to bring change of clothes(the kids get wet, sweaty or muddy!), drink and food. Not a lot of drink and food is sold at the shop. Cotton gloves are included in the fee. Most of the equipments’ level is good for elementary schools kids and above, some 4 or 5yo can enjoy them too. There is a free parking in front of the entrance, but most of the time it gets full quite quickly after opening.

Love this place - the playground is huge with a lot of nice slides. The 50 stations with challenges are awesome for the kids and even challenging for adults :-).
Prices are reasonable, parking available!

Parking is free but gets full and overflow parking is a 5-10min walk. The most of the obstacle courses are not for toddlers, preschoolers, or if you have a fear of heights. There's a place to grill and plenty of picnic benches to sit and relax. Well worth the admission fee (¥3K for family of 4).

During my weekend visit, the park was as crowded as expected. It's a bit of a distance from the nearest train station, so if you're using public transport, be prepared for a walk. The park itself is quite spacious, covering a large area. Most of the obstacles are challenging and suitable for kids aged 7-8 and above. However, there are a few obstacles with attached slides that are designed for younger kids. It's a good idea to bring spare clothes as the ones they're wearing will likely get dirty. One notable section of the park features obstacles in a pond, which is quite popular. Overall, it's a great place for kids to burn off some energy. However, if you have a toddler who isn't as agile as others, you may be limited to just one or two obstacles.
I find a great place to take the family and kids to get out all their energy and be adventurous and get some exercise.

reviews.text: Great visit to the stadium to see Yokohama play.  Very different experience to British Football matches, with a great atmosphere and lots of young kids and even babies.  If you get a chance visit a Japanese football match.

One of the famous and biggest park. It have many times park parking facility.
And many foot ball courts. Have rest room
Running tracks are so nice. Seperate athlete ground also available it's near to the Nissan stadium
Kids play area also available. The river nearby give good atmosphere for you and your family.. Just walking around with your pets also possible
There are some pets play ground available
It's good for a family outing day. Many clubs meet at the weekend and weekdays for the sports meet.
Running clubs also available here
You can get get the volunteer for if a disable person(those who not able to see) wants to run.. Or jog .
Overall it will give a positive attitude and encouragement &good vibes..
So overall good experience
A great park with tennis courts, skate park, basketball courts, dog area and football fields
I love the skate park! The park as a whole has every sport you can think of

Not been here on one the match days. But here on a quite Thursday evening. Mega structure and very well maintained. Stunning view from outside. Beside shin Yokohama park.
Long running/jogging tracks.

Cute park at the top of Motomachi exit 6 in Yokohama. This cozy park is hidden at the top of the station and next to the foreign peoples cemetery. Can get a little busy on the weekend, but if you have time to wander around it is a nice starting point before heading to Yamashita park or some of the surrounding cafes.
April 23rd. Roses have not bloomed yet. Maybe next week.

Christmas time lightup is the best!

It isn't busy like some other larger parks in the area, so you can actually have a romantic christmas-y stroll for real.

Better than the packed midtown illumination if you ask me!

Relax and chill place.
You can come here for rose (May) and illumination (winter time) and have some view of Minato. It’s close to Minato-no-mieru park

Nice relaxing park nearby a shopping mall and cable car.
Nice park with grass area. Near world porters.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-1-1 Minatomirai, Nishi Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 220-0012, Japan
data.name: Rinko Park

reviews.text: Great waterfront park. Beautiful views of Yokohama Bay and the iconic skyline, wide open spaces, lush greenery, and scenic walking paths. Ideal for picnics, leisurely strolls, and photography. The promenade walk is literally at the level of the ocean.
The park is spacious, clean and beautiful, it is located next to the beach. You can go for a walk and see beautiful sea views.
Beautiful park with a lot of open area for family activities, tents and bay view. Come here to let the kids run and for the parents to relax. Most parents are enjoying a wine or beer.

This park is very beautiful because we can see the sea directly. It will be very beautiful if you come here at dusk and see the sunset. I also saw many people fishing freely here, both children and adults. Maybe it would be very suitable as a place for a family weekend holiday. To get here you can come via Minato Mirai Station and walk for about 5 minutes. It’s very recommended garden.
Beautiful peaceful park slightly off the beaten path, well worth the diversion. Amazing views of Yokohama waterside.

reviews.text: Harbor View park has probably one of the most magnificent views of the harbor, which makes sense due to the name..obviously. It was so clean and refreshing i felt almost cleansed after going for a peaceful stroll through the park. all the flowers surrounding you everywhere, it was honestly beautiful. i do recommend going for anyone who loves flowers and peaceful walks through parks as this is one of the best parks i went to!
Beautiful park when roses are in full blossom. Best time to visit, mid / end of May.
Quaint little park for you to stroll around or jog. Very nice observatory in top looking out to the city and ocean. You can see Gundam Factory from the observatory as well.
Wonderful hillside park with beautiful gardens and great views of the harbor.

A big of rose garden and free of cost.
About 10 mins walk from Motomachi-Chukagainstation.
As the name, you can have a view of Yokohama port from the observatory spot.

Also there is bus from Yokohama station.

So it is accessible very easily. However you will need to walk up hill a bit.

Roses blossom usually in May.

reviews.text:
Nice display of Sakura trees but far short of 200 trees claimed by concierge.

Is it worth making a special trip to look? If you have lots of time to spare?!

Look at my photos. If you like, then go and have a look

Very beautiful park. You can see the Yokohama Tower from here and the park itself is wide so you can run around or even ride your bicycle . I went through this everyday when I was studying in a college in Yokohama . Also during spring this place get filled with Sakura. Great place to relax from the busy streets below

Not too big Park but nice view surrounded by Sakura.
There's Kamon statue represented for the person who attributed for open trading with other countries (American, Europe)
Great spot to hanami and see landmark tower from a distance. Has a very local vibe to it. No soft grass but the amount of Sakura trees makes up for it.
A nice and less crowded park. Went there for ohanami with couchsurf friends. I like this place compare to Tokyo. :>

reviews.text: Small quiet park on a high hill. Good place for families on weekends.

Good park near the busstop Asahidai ,Tsurumi.
Cherry blossoms are beautifully blooming.
Nice playground

A park located in a residential area with many hills, 12 minutes from Tsurumi Station.
There is a jungle gym, slide, swings, sandbox, and drinking fountain. There are few parks around here.

This is a quiet park located in a residential area.
It's well kept and I think it's suitable for families.
It's a reasonable size for children to play, there are benches, and there are vending machines across the street from the park, so you don't have to worry about staying hydrated.
The surrounding roads are sloped, so I think it's good for exercise.
Please note that there is no place to park your car.

What a historical site and can feel the ancient people way of live. Nice environment. The entrance is free.

Great insight into Yayoi culture. Best to be visited together with the museum. The park is nice also.

data.formatted_address: 3-chōme-33-2 Tsuruyachō, Kanagawa Ward, Yokohama, Kanagawa 221-0835, Japan
data.name: Hideharu Fukasaku Gallery & Museum

reviews.text:
Beautiful art museum close to Yokohama station.

Some exposition are free entrance.

The staff are really kind

This is a gallery I have visited several times.
This time I visited to see a group exhibition titled ``Fushikaden''.
It was my first time seeing the work of Aya Tamiya, the main visual, and it was really wonderful.
It was a wonderful exhibition with many other high-quality works lined up.

"Holding solo exhibitions in a stylish space based on white"

I heard on a radio program that pencil artist Atsushi Shibata was having a solo exhibition here, so I went to see him.
In the program, it was said that the results looked just like photographs, and people who saw them were surprised.It certainly seems like there were many works that were overflowing with kindness, but I think it would be an exaggeration to say that they looked like photographs. thought. But on the other hand, I was impressed by the gentle touch that only a pencil can provide.
There are about 20 works, and most of them are for sale.
It's a shame that Yokohama isn't very accessible by car from the Tama area, so you can't easily go there. It only took about 30 minutes, so I wish I had decided on somewhere else to go.

I went on the last day of the Printsaurus International Print Exchange Association exhibition🎨

It was my first time, so it was hard to know where to go, but I was fine on my way back😊

I was able to take my time to look at it and enjoy it, but I guess one of the difficulties of exhibiting it is that the outside scenery is reflected in the works on the walls facing the road, and I can see myself reflected in the glass.

But I thoroughly enjoyed it😃

It's a little walk from the station.
On rainy days, we recommend going underground.
